title: john bercow out of parliament tories replace him
story: Today the chairman of the Tory Buckingham association is meeting the Conservative party’s national head of candidate selection Gareth Fox to find a suitable figure to fight the seat.He wants the party to start advertising the position from today.The Speaker has stood unopposed in his Buckingham seat since standing down as a Tory MP in  to take the neutral role of Speaker.But the Tories are hoping he will quit before the next election to free up the seat.The move will put pressure on Mr Bercow amid the outrage over claims he is helping Remainer MPs thwart Brexit in the Commons.When he was elected in  Mr Bercow had pledged to only serve until  but has cited the uncertainty over Brexit to justy staying on.It was understood he would only extend his tenure until June this year but Tories now fear he will use the deepening Brexit crisis to cling on longer and even beyond the next General Electiona snap vote is called.But that would be the fourth General Election in a row at which the Buckingham seat is left uncontested.Buckingham Tory association chairman Cllr Clive Harriss said anger was rising among constituents over their lack of a choice for MP at elections.He said the party would traditionally only start looking for a new candidate when the Speaker stands down.But he told The Sun: “We’ve started to put feelers out with a view we’ll have someone in place soan election is calledhe decides not to stand we’ll have someone in place to fight the seat in the normal way.“I’ll be talking to central office on Friday to make sure they advertise the position.”However he admitted the party has “absolutely no influence” over when Mr Bercow decides to stand down.Mr Harriss added: “We don’t know what’s going to happenthere is a General Election.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no delaying halting brexit john mann
story: Across the country people who voted dferent ways in the Brexit referendum are ­becoming bored and irritated by the silly games at Westminster.The truth is that a large majority of MPs are Remainers in their hearts and souls and are struggling to bring themselves to recognise the reality of the situation.It was us MPs who voted to give you, the people, the say on leaving or remaining in the European Union.And you voted, in higher numbers than you have ever bothered voting for any of us.Yet the same MPs who gave you a say are coming up with every excuse for why your views should not be listened to.Of course there are Remainer MPs whose constituencies voted heavily to remain.There are MPs with, I have to say it, courage, who have always argued strongly in a way that they have always known is dferent to their ­voters. These people are ­consistent and have my respect.But there are just as many who are in danger now of sitting on the fence until rigor mortis sets in, coming up with process rather than substance.They are simply hoping that others will do the dirty deed and respect the will of the people.It is also, for every Labour and Conservative MP, the manesto ­promise that we stood on at the last election. We voted for a referendum. We promised to respect the result.We got re-elected promising the same, yet Parliament continues to sit on the roundabout to nowhere.It is time to stop the shenanigans and work across the political ide to bring our country and our people together.At stake is our democracy. And in a democracy the winner prevails.Of course, in future years, people can argue that we have got it wrong and that people are entitled to change their mind. But for democracy to be true and real, we have to deliver the mandate we have been given and leave the EU on March .The referendum ided people and families, with lots of strong and dfering views. But in cherishing our democracy, we now need to come together to deliver a Brexit that respects the people’s vote and helps heal that ide.In le we have to compromise. We all have our own perfect Brexit, me included. And with ten of my colleagues we have forced through a big part of that, guaranteeing in law workers’ rights, health and safety and environmental standards. We will be competing with Europe by being the best, not by being the cheapest.I would love to have been a fly on the wall when Theresa May told union bosses that she was meeting their key demands not just with a promise but with a legal guarantee. But then she knew it was only right, because union members were the bedrock of leave voters across the country.And, I believe, we can get more in the next fortnight. title: this morning nta ally ross tv opinion
story: Six days a week now, This Morning hammers home the message its viewers are the most helpless, mollycoddled invertebrates on the planet.A form of le so useless that last November Dr Chris Steele, the show’s resident quack, genuinely felt the need to give us all bottom-wiping advice.“It’s a front-to-back action for women,” more of a hit-and-hope exercise for men.Infor this constant nannying, we pick up a phone once a year and gurgle: “You’re absolutely right. We are useless. Have a trophy.”And it’s a depressing cycle that will continue for as long as there are National Television Awards, live from The O.A ceremony where the categories may chop and change every year, but the stupidity remains ritualised.As well as getting all the usual winners though, viewers also had to endure a technical nightmare on Tuesday, where things went wrong — from the shambolic opening scenes right through to the unedited version of the closing credits: “With thanks to — Television Centre White City or just Television Centretoo long.”It’s always a case of fine margins, of course, at the NTAs, and the evening might have strayed into so-bad-it’s-good territorythe cameras had just focused on one of the Love Island gang when host Dermot O’Leary said: “Danny DeVito will be in Dumbo next year.”They didn’t, though. So a night bedevilled by sound issues, rotten acceptance speeches and foul Danny Dyer language was crowned by Special Recognition winner David Dimbleby eulogising the BBC and ordering us to be nicer to politicians, in a speech that could hardly be descri- bed as “mood capturing”.It’s the awards themselves though, that I know get viewers’ goats the most, starting, painful as it is to admit, with the fact perennial winners This Morning absolutely robbed Piers Morgan’s Good Morning Britain operation in the Daytime category.Given that Jack Whitehall’s Travels With My Father managed to scrape on to the Comedy shortlist, there’s also an argument that says Chunk, Charlotte Hawkins, Richard Arnold and Susanna Reid — who was styled quite magnicently on the night as Waitrose’s answer to Vicky Pattison — should have made that final five as well.Because almost no show made me laugh as loud or as regularly as Good Morning Britain did in .A glaring omission too in the TV Judge section — always won by David Walliams — which included X Factor’s Robbie Williams on the shortlist, but not Craig Revel Horwood, who didn’t take a two-week sabbatical in the middle of Strictly, cost the BBC £million or throw in his other half as part of the deal.The award that made a nonsense of the whole occasion though was Ant  Dec winning Best Presenters for the th time in a row, despite the presence of Bradley Walsh and Graham Norton on the shortlist, and the fact Ant spent far more weeks in rehab than he did in a TV studio.The mutual affection is touching in one way, of course, but it ultimately does neither them nor the NTAs any good at all and has robbed both of a glorious moment of redemption when they win the  award.Before that foregone conclusion takes place, please stay tuned to This Morning and sit tight until mid-March, when Dr Chris will be along with part II of his bottom-wiping masterclass: Flushing, FLU-SHING.Practially the only programme I watched at the weekend that wasn’t punctuated by uncontrollable sobbing fits from the participants was BBC’s landmark Holocaust documentary The Last Survivors.Men and women who are all in their late eighties and nineties now and understand that time is precious.When you’re a living part of history you also know facts are far more precious than tears.So in the words of the remarkable Anita Lasker-Wallfisch, who avoided the Auschwitz gas chamber purely because she could play the cello: “I won’t give people the pleasure of seeing my emotions.”The very least we owe all of them is an audience. The Last Survivors is available on the BBC iPlayer and will probably be the most unforgettable  minutes of television you’ll watch all year.At approximately : hours, Sunday, Gemma Collins stumbled over while Dancing On Ice.The tectonic plates groaned a little on impact, the front row scattered like ten pins and there was a surge on the national grid as several million viewers went “click, rewind, play,” then “click, rewind, play,” again.In fact, by the time I’d stopped rewinding and playing, Gemma had “bounced back,”and Piers Morgan, no doubt angling for a Le Stories interview, had claimed it was “the gutsiest thing I’ve seen on a talent show” – probably since the days Piers himself was wedged in behind the judges’ desk on Britain’s Got Talent.It was an undeniably great television moment, though.A proper face plant, with a full Klinsmann snow plough to finish.The downside, obviously, is that it’s guaranteed she’ll be back next week, when Melody, Wes, James and the others will be performing to a Fairytale theme and Gemma will be clearing the B Fettercairn to Banchory road,ITV want to find a proper use for her.Click, rewind, play.Things remain cheerful as hell on EastEnders.Alfie Moon’s car has been discovered near some clfs and a policeman has the job of breaking the most awful news imaginable to Kat and the Slaters.“Considering the location and the evidence at hand, we would suggest you prepare yourself for the worst.”Big Mo: “You understand what they’re saying ”Yes, bloody Redwater’s getting a second series. Stay strong, viewers.Celebrity Coach Trip, Roxanne Pallett: “I knew as soon as Jedward got on the coach it was going to be fun.”The One Show, Matt Baker: “If you haven’t seen The Greatest Dancer yet, watch it on the iPlayer. It’s well worth it.”And Icons, Kathleen Turner: “Charlie Chaplin used his films to try and smash social barriers.”No, Charlie Chaplin used his films to try and make people laugh.Tell the BBC to try it some time.Good Morning Britain, Piers Morgan: “Every cloud. We lost the NTA, but I got a kiss off Gemma Collins.” Yeah, every cloud’s got a gigantic p***-storm.No one from Peaky Blinders bothering to turn up to the NTAs to thank: “The best fans a show could hope for.”Celebrity Coach Trip contestants Jedward ­providing the finest argument yet for theof a hard Irish border.Sheridan Smith’s accent doing the London to Doncaster trip in . seconds flat, on that Cleaning Up tosh.The Greatest Dancer’s pre-performance sob stories straying horribly close to moral blackmail territory.And E fly-on-the-wall moron Vogue Williams asking: “Is Gandhi the Dalai Lama ” in total ­ignorance of this remarkable man’s wisdom, serenity and even his landmark campaign for Dolce  Gabbana’s Light Blue fragrance . . .Martin Keown: “It should be a great spectacle, so sit back, hide behind the sofa and enjoy it.”Phil Thompson: “You never know what’s going to happen and that’s exactly what happened.”And Paul Merson: “If he was at Arsenal doing this, he wouldn’t be doing it.”.This week’s winner is the bellowing great Orca herself, Gemma Collins, and Sugar, from Total Drama Island.Sent in by Rich, of Lincolnshire. title: nick timothy brady brexit vote
story: With the deadlock among MPs still not broken, nobody knows for sure what will happen.Theresa May says Brexit must go ahead on time. But she also says Britain will not leave the EU without a deal.And her deal — the only one on the table at this late stage — was defeated in the House of Commons by a record majority just two weeks ago.Tonight’s Brexit votes are not quite the final shoot-out between the dferent factions in Parliament. The Government has promised that MPs will vote soon on a new plan.Remainers and soft Brexit supporters in government are pushing to hold that vote as soon as possible.And MPs — backed by a Speaker who will rewrite any Commons rules to soften or stop Brexit — will force more votes on what happens next.Nevertheless, tonight’s votes do matter.One proposal comes from Yvette Cooper, a Labour MP.Her Yorkshire constituents voted to leave the EU by more than two to one and, during the election, she promised them she would “not vote to block Brexit.”Yet that is what her plan does:     MPs vote for her   amendment, they will be able to stop Brexit happening this year.Cooper has the support of several rebel Tories, soJeremy Corbyn whips his MPs to vote for it, she stands a good chance of getting her way.Caroline Spelman and Jack Dromey, Conservative and Labour, have an amendment that calls on the Government to avoid a no-deal Brexit.Dominic Grieve wants MPs to control the Commons timetable, allowing Parliament to vote on dferent ways of watering Brexit down.Labour want to present MPs with options that include, predictably, a second referendum.Despite drafting a manesto saying “Labour accepts the referendum result”, the Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer says in a second referendum he would campaign to overturn the result of the first.It is possible that none of these amendments might pass.Remainers and soft Brexiteers are ided about what should happen.Some want to delay Brexit, some want to tie us to European rules and regulations, and others want another referendum to stop it altogether.Evenno proposal wins a Commons majority, the votes cast by MPs will probably demonstrate that there is a majority to water down Brexit one way or another.For Brexit supporters, this is very dangerous indeed.Some believe they simply need to run down the clock and, in  days, we can leave without a deal.For Leavers who want a negotiated departure, this feels like a serious risk.But Leavers who favour no deal need to ask themselves, can they really be so sure they will get what they want With several Cabinet ministers, many more junior ministers and a Commons majority against no deal, it seems increasingly likely that MPs will ultimately find a way of stopping no deal.When they do, Brexit will only get softer and softer.This is why the amendment proposed by Graham Brady, a senior Conservative, is so important.His idea is to approve the Prime Minister’s original Brexit deal, but with the “backstop” removed.The backstop is hated by unionists, because to prevent barriers to trade between Ireland and Northern Ireland, it creates new barriers to trade between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK.And it is hated by Leavers, because it ties the UK to the EU’s customs union, and Northern Ireland to EU single market rules.Brady wants MPs to vote simply for “alternative arrangements” to the backstop.By avoiding a specic proposal, he hopes the amendment can win a Commons majority and, in doing so, demonstrate to Brussels that the deal they struck with Theresa May can be ratied — but only without the backstop.Critics, largely Remainers, say this is impossible.But in the past week or so, Angela Merkel has questioned whether the backstop is such a good idea after all.The Polish foreign minister has suggested it should expire after five years. And the European Commission effectively conceded that in the event of no deal, they would use policy and technology to prevent a hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland.In other words, they proposed solutions they once dismissed as “unicorns” and “magical thinking” when they were suggested by the British — and which could render the backstop unnecessary.But this is not all. Some European officials have floated, in private, a more inventive solution: that the UK and Ireland should form a British Isles customs zone, with Britain compensating Ireland for any new friction in their trade with Europe.So it is clear: whatever Remainers claim, alternatives to the backstop are technically and politically feasible.Recognising this, the Brady amendment would give the Government one last chance to negotiate something better.Yet Tory Brexiteers say they might not vote for it. They fear the ambiguity of “alternative arrangements” could allow ministers to negotiate an even worse deal, perhaps tying the whole of the UK to the EU’s customs union and single market rules for good.They do not trust May, her advisers, or most of her Cabinet and demand a specic time limit on the backstop.Butthey vote down the Brady amendment, they will not get what they want, and are more likely to get what they fear.As the clock ticks on and bottoms get even squeakier, MPs will coalesce around a plan to stop a no-deal Brexit.The EU will have no reason to compromise, and Parliament will soften our departure by aligning us with more and more European laws.If Leavers vote against Brady, they will be shooting themselves not in one foot, and not even in both feet, but in the head.As the Commons debates the proposals today, Leavers need to start compromising with reality.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nick clegg job fix facebook molly russell
story: The former Deputy Prime Minister, last seen being booted out by the voters of Sheffield Hallam, has re-emerged as Facebook’s Mr Fixit — the man tasked by its CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, with rescuing the reputation of the embattled internet firm.Having claimed that “I actually find the messianic Calornian new-worldy-touchy-feely culture of Facebook a little grating”, Sir Nick has duly installed himself in a £million mansion near San Francisco, ready to offer his expertise.Some people have been puzzled about why the world’s most powerful social media company, owner of Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp, would recruit a man whose main brush with online fame was an autotuned video of him apologising for betraying the public over tuition fees.In fact, Clegg and Zuckerberg are a match made in heaven. Both are powered by an inexorable sense of self-righteousness. And both have an awful lot of experience of saying sorry.The most recent example came when Sir Nick appeared on the BBC in the wake of the furore over the death of -year-old Molly Russell.It turned out, after she was found dead in her bedroom in December , that she had been viewing material online relating to depression, self-harm and suicide — material which was shockingly easy to find.As her father Ian Russell put it bluntly: “Instagram helped kill my daughter.”Sir Nick, to his credit, said all the right things about how the firm was determined to do more. But he also made the striking claim that it is sometimes better for Facebook and Instagram to keep suicide images online, because it helps other vulnerable young people get support.This after The Sun, on Saturday, found and flagged up multiple images appearing to normalise and even romanticise suicide, all within a few clicks. Many remained published for days, and a Facebook spokesman claimed they could be beneficial to users battling mental health issues.Sir Nick says the firm is following the advice from leading experts and charities. And it may well be doing the right thing. But this is the latest example of Facebook — and other social media giants in general — only acting to tackle a problem once it becomes impossible not to.Over the past decade, social media has come to dominate our lives. The latest research from Ofcom shows internet use rocketing among children and teenagers, with friendships and social lives increasingly run through screens and phones.And it is now clear that this great move online has been accompanied, for our children, by a staggering increase in mental health problems.The situation is particularly alarming when it comes to young women. The latest NHS data found that one in four of those aged  to  report having a mental health disorder — twice the rate among boys.In  alone, one in five US girls aged between  and  suffered a major depressive episode — one in five! Suicide rates for teenage girls, according to academic Jonathan Haidt, have risen by  per cent in the US and  per cent in the UK in a decade.This isn’t just about what happens on the internet. Those having problems online often tend to be experiencing problems offline too, such as bullying, harassment or broken families.More broadly, Haidt believes the “snowflake” phenomenon reflects that “helicopter parenting” leaves children less prepared to cope with shocks and dficulty. But the internet, and social media, are very clearly intensying those problems. And the big tech firms are still playing catch-up.The traditional argument from Silicon Valley is that it’s not their job to regulate human behaviour. They add that eventhey wanted to, there is simply too much out there.They are doing their best to crack down on inappropriate content, but it’s like trying to stem the tide. Behind the scenes — they insist — thousands of people are working day and night to detect and delete messages promoting terrorism, hatred, Holocaust denial and self-harm.But this argument just doesn’t wash. It’s very clear that, in the interests of their bottom lines, many of the big social media firms have long failed to put enough resources into detecting damaging content.Researchers have shown, for example, how following the recommended links from reputable YouTube content can lead to a carnival of horrors. News reports that segue into crackpot conspiracy theories and videos for toddlers that give way to horrendous scenes of a bloodied Minnie Mouse trapped in an escalator.Every day brings new horror stories, such as rival fans of royals Kate and Meghan using the Kensington Palace Instagram to send death threats to each other. Increasingly, online hate is triggering real-le violence. The slaughter of the Rohingya Muslims in Burma was, The New York Times said, “a genocide incited on Facebook”.Part of the reason that Zuckerberg has hired Clegg is to put his house in order. Clegg has talked the right talk about changing Facebook’s culture, and in particular doing more to tackle self-harm.He even says they might start paying more tax. ButZuckerberg’s answer to “how to fix the internet” is “hire Nick Clegg”, we have still got an awfully long way to go.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eu backstop brexit nonsense
story: Will Eurocrats cause needless ­disruption just to make a point  Would they rather see all sides suffer than watch a post-EU Britain succeed If so, what would it say about the ­organisation we are leaving Let’s take a moment to recap.Immediately after the referendum, EU officials declared they would not talk to Britain about a long-term relationship until we first agreed withdrawal terms, including a “orce payment”, rights for EU citizens and the Irish border.Britain foolishly agreed. It was ­particularly silly to discuss Ireland before the main trade talks, since the obvious way to prevent a hard border on the island is through a deep and ­comprehensive trade agreement between the UK and the EU as a whole.That, though, would have given Ireland a strong incentive to get the best possible terms for the UK, and for itself.So instead, at the end of , the EU suddenly came up with the idea of an “Irish backstop”.It wanted Britain to promise that, unless it came up with a long-term ­trading ­relationship that satisfied ­Brussels, it would stay in the customs union and leave Northern Ireland under EU regulations.Stupidly, British negotiators accepted the backstop. Wisely, our MPs did not.The backstop would mean Brussels continued to control Britain’s trade deals with non-European countries after we left.It would mean placing part of our country under permanent EU jurisdiction.MPs threw the deal out. Then something sensible happened.Leavers and Remainers began to talk directly to each other and hammered out a deal that both sides could live with.There were lots of aspects of the ­withdrawal agreement that Eurosceptics resented.They didn’t like being non- voting members for another  months.They didn’t like Euro judges continuing to rule here even after we had left.They didn’t like forking out more than billion quid in exchange for the better part of bugger all.But they were ready to make ­compromises. If the Irish ­backstop were removed, they’d swallow the rest of the withdrawal terms.On Tuesday, the House of Commons adopted this position. The EU responded with a theatrical snort of indignation.“We stand by the agreement that we have negotiated,” said Michel Barnier, the European Commission’s negotiator.“The withdrawal agreement is not ­renegotiable,” said Jean-Claude Juncker, President of the European Commission.But hang on. Juncker is simultaneously telling us thatwe alter our red lines — by, for example, agreeing to a ­permanent customs union — then the agreement could indeed be reopened.So there is plainly no technical or legal reason why the backstop could not be removed or at least time-limited.Nor, by the way, is anyone still ­pretending that, without the backstop, there will be checkpoints in Londonderry and Crossmaglen.The Irish government has confirmed that,there is no deal, it will not place any infrastructure at the border.The British Government has been saying the same all along.Barnier says there would be ways to carry out necessary checks away from the frontier.In other words, the whole row is about a border that no one is going to build anyway.It’s ­surreal. There is plainly no way the House of Commons is going to accept the backstop.It also became clear on ­Tuesday there is no majority for a ­second ­referendum, because the last thing Jeremy Corbyn wants is to have to come down on one side or the other.That leaves only two options. Either the backstop is dropped but everything  is agreed, or the backstop is lost and so is everything .From the EU’s point of view, it must surely be preferable to agree the bulk of the Withdrawal Agreement, including reciprocal citizens’ rights and the ­£billion payment, while finding an alternative way to guarantee the Irish border stays open.From Dublin’s point of view, the logic is even stronger.Insisting on the backstop risks,not a hard border, certainly more dislocation between the Republic of Ireland and the UK — the very thing the backstop is ­supposed to prevent.The EU has calculated the cost will be worse for Britain than for ­Continental states, since cross-Channel trade is ­proportionately more important for us.But, by that measure, it is more ­important still for Ireland.In private, some Continental politicians are pushing for a pragmatic outcome — one that minimises disruption and ­preserves the long-term alliance between the UK and its neighbours.You especially hear these arguments in countries that trade heavily with Britain, such as Denmark and the Netherlands.You also hear them from governments that want to ensure the rights of their citizens in Britain are guaranteed.But for Eurocrats, in particular the anti-British Martin Selmayr who has seized control of negotiations, this isn’t about finding an outcome that works.If it were, the EU could have signed a continuity deal with Britain easily.The truth is many Euro-fanatics are happy to inflict pain on the EU  ­provided they inflict even more on us.If their view prevails over that of the pragmatists, then Britain has no option but to leave without an agreement. It is never sensible to give into blackmail.If the choice is between No Deal and surrendering part of our country, we will choose No Deal.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. url: https://www.thesun.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/NINTCHDBPICT0004622820533.jpg?strip=all&w=960&quality=100" alt="Tories, whether they're for Leave or Remain, must be united behind the PM and Brexit" width="960
title: tories must remain united on brexit
story: IT is vital that the Tories reflect on their new unity and vow to maintain it. Because it could all be reversed in a fortnight — and the EU is counting on it.That’s why, despite the world watching to seeit is capable of reasonable ­compromise, its eurocrats remained so pig-headedly defiant yesterday.Their confected rage and ridiculous pretence at still being confused over what Britain wants are stalling tactics.The hope being that in the new round of votes on February  Tory Remainers, some in Cabinet, blink first. That this time they back a motion preventing us leaving without a deal on March , setting up the potential reversal of Brexit.They must not. The cost to the country and their party will be catastrophic.The Sun does not want No Deal but the threat of it is our greatest leverage. We must not give it up.It is equally dangerousBrexiteers overplay their hand. They have pushed Theresa May in the right direction — but they must now be realistic. If the EU does finally offer some meaningful legal commitment on the backstop they must take it.The PM’s deal will be softer than they want. But hold out for more and Brexit could be lost. A Remainer-stuffed ­Parliament may see to that, however bullish eurosceptic MPs are today.Meanwhile, two things must happen: While No Deal is still possible we must turbo-charge our preparations for it.And Brussels must be left in no doubt . . . not one penny of our exit bill will be paidit happens.IRELAND’S naive PM Leo Varadkar will deserve much of the blame for the misery and chaos No Deal would unleash on his people and across Europe.“We could find ourselves in  or  weeks’ time needing to find a lot of money to save people’s jobs,” he admits.It is time, then, for him to stop posing as a hardman and do the right thing.It is absurd hyperbole to claim Ireland would be betrayed by giving us a legally binding escape option from the backstop at some hypothetical future point.A hard border will happen onlyEU obstinacy pushes us into No Deal. It will then be needed rapidly, as Brussels says.Varadkar’s continued posturing is suicidal. It’s time to be a real statesman.THERESA May needs her most experienced, hard-bitten negotiators in Brussels.The EU is now represented by Martin ­Selmayr, the bullying German eurocrat bent on punishing Britain. So it is vital we deploy the legal skills of Attorney General Geoffrey Cox alongside tough Kiwi trade expert Crawford Falconer.Forget the europhile civil servant Olly Robbins.We need heavier hitters.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: foreign aid source of corruption
story: Can I start the ball rolling  And maybe then you’d like to hear from a few readers. The people who can’t get beds in our hospitals, or a place for their kids in the local school. All the while that £billion is being spent on fabulously berserk ­projects in the developing world.To her total credit, Mordaunt has said that our current level of spending on overseas aid is unsustainable. It’s been rising every year. Due to a law passed by the coalition government, we have to spend . per cent of our income on aid to the Third World each year.So right now we spend just under £billion. And where does this money go  No less than  per cent of it is siphoned off to global outfits like that most useless of organisations, the United Nations.This is the body which sent out some dimbo Australian envoy to tick off our Government about economic policy. An organisation which elected Saudi Arabia on to its Women’s Rights Commission. An anti-Western and rabidly anti-Israeli convocation of leftie Third World thugs with chips on their shoulders.The world would be enormously improvedthe UN was shut down tomorrow. And the rest of it  Some of the stuff you wouldn’t believe. A total of £, went to a project investigating Tibetan verbs. Nope, not kidding.I would assume that “climb” was one of the verbs they were investigating. They use that a lot, over there. Thanks to our overseas aid, someone, ­somewhere is now able to say in Tibetan: “F*** me, is that a yeti  Run away!”Then there’s the £, spent on a scheme to stop Indian schoolchildren imbibing sugary drinks. India itself gives overseas aid and has an income rather bigger than our own. Where is the point Another six-figure sum was spent ­persuading Chinese people not to smoke too much — China! The second richest country in the world.Another one was to help Indian workers cool their work­stations down — this in a country which has its own space programme, for Chrissakes. So much of our money is swallowed up by useless leftie quangos and charities to keep themselves in jobs.Still more is pocketed by despots in the horrible countries they run. It is a source of corruption and dependency. It makes things worse. And when we tried to ert our overseas aid to some of the Caribbean countries stricken by hurricanes we were told we couldn’t — they were too rich!It’s a nonsense and a racket. If I thought our overseas aid, in its current form, really alleviated misery and suffering I’d be all for it. That’s why I agreed with the last secretary of state, Priti Patel, who wanted to give a decent chunk to the Israel Defence Forces, which saves a lot of lives in Syria.So my recommendation would be to end it all NOW. Divert the money into our beleaguered and creaking infrastructure. And when a tragedy occurs overseas — sure, splash the cash.Anyway, Penny — hope I’ve helped by starting the conversation. Over to you, babes.SCOTTISH politician Ross Greer has already been called a “ginger turd” by Piers Morgan, and I don’t think I can improve on that. But it’s his ignorance and stupidity that staggers – rather than his hatred for Great Britain, which is something we’re used to from north of the border.Greer described Winston Churchill as a white supremacist, a mass murderer and a racist, and likened him to Soviet dictator Joseph Stalin. He says he is simply challenging the “myth” of Churchill. No, Ross, you’re not.You’re just pig ignorant, with a very poor grasp of history. Of course Churchill was racist. Just about everybody was of his age at that time.If you can’t see the importance of Churchill to winning the Second World War – against REAL racists, REAL mass murderers – when Britain stood alone, then you lack all sense of context and proportion.The more I think about it, the more I reckon “ginger turd” was an understatement.HERO of the week is the excellent Rachel Riley, who has been speaking out against anti-Semitism. As a consequence, she now needs greater security when she’s doing TV’s ­Countdown. The left-wing Jew-hating trolls have been after her.Rachel,  said: “The more I speak, the more abuse I get, and the more abuse I get, the more I speak. It’s got to the point where I can’t look at my Twitter feed any more. It’s just a constant stream.”She’s pretty clear who is behind it, too.  A lot of the abuse comes from people who sign off with the hashtag JCPM.SO, Labour MP Fiona Onasanya is off to prison. Found guilty in court of lying through her teeth.But the remarkable thing is she’s still going to be paid as an MP while she’s inside. She has refused to resign her seat and so her £, salary will continue to be paid by the rest of us.If you got sent to the nick, do you think your employers would continue to pay your wages  You’d be out on your ear. It’s kind of ­outrageous, no THIS cultural appropriation business is getting out of hand. Marks  Spencer has been slammed by leftie nutters with nothing better to do with their time. For selling a biryani wrap.They say it’s not authentic. Well of course it’s not bleedin’ authentic.  This is the UK, not Mumbai. Singer Katy Perry was attacked for wearing a kimono because she isn’t Japanese.White people in the US get criticised for wearing training shoes or sporting afros – that’s appropriating black culture, apparently. Though I think it was white folks who invented training shoes. Thing is, cultural appropriation is brilliant.It’s the way we have of sharing our respective cultures.  think it’s wonderful that countries outside Europe and the US have “culturally appropriated” democracy, sanitisation, railways, computers and so on. I wish more would do the same.SOMALIA is the most corrupt country in the world, according to a list compiled by a group called Transparency International.Not a great surprise, is it  Nor to see most of the rest of Africa hogging the bottom quarter of the world table.It’s bad governance and corruption that is keeping Africa poor – not colonialism. You can tell that the compilers of the report are lefties, though. Asked what countries were becoming more corrupt recently, they named the US, Hungary and Brazil. All three have elected right-wing governments.A NEW study says that women who wear short skirts are more likely to be ­promoted.The lesson I’d take from this,I were a women, is to wear a short skirt to work. But I don’t think that’s the lesson they mean us to take.I wonderwomen who wear short skirts but have the legs of an obese ­elephant also are more likely to get ­promoted I think that’s the next study for those researchers at the ­University of Surrey.I TOLD you last week that the reason we haven’t had a proper winter yet is that the people who run winter couldn’t agree on stuff.Such as whether it should be a hard winter, with lots of snow, no winter at all or a compromise deal with a backstop of some sleet for a bit.But I understand that on Tuesday the President of ­Winter won an astonishing ­victory and was able to push her deal through.Which was why it immediately snowed like hell.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: vaping more effective patches gum
story: Almost two in ten e-cig users kicked the habit after a year compared with one in ten on other aids.But researchers found vapers risk swapping one addiction for another, with the majority of quitters becoming hooked.They analysed  adults at NHS stop smoking services.Half were given e-cigs and half nicotine replacement treatments including patches, gum, lozenges and sprays.Nearly  per cent of vapers were still doing it a year later compared to . per cent on other nicotine fixes. Health professionals have been reluctant to recommend their use because of the lack of clear evidence from randomised trials. It was entirely his responsibility.”Sherf Christine McCrossan fined Halon £.

title: downing street shake up brexit negotiators
story: Just  hours after the PM’s Commons victory on Tuesday night, Tory MPs’ delicate truce also began to crack when loyalist ministers accused hardliners of tricking Theresa May.Arch Tory Eurosceptics say Theresa May’s chief of staff Gavin Barwell had promised to bring in two seasoned trade negotiators as part of a deal for their votes.The European Research Group want the UK’s Permanent Representative to the WTO Julian Braithwaite and the Department for International Trade’s chief negotiator Crawford Falconer to go to Brussels for new talks.But No yesterday insisted there were would be “no change” to the PM’s team, and it will still be lead by Whitehall mandarin Olly Robbins.Angry former Tory leader Iain Duncan-Smith branded the U-turn “absurd”.After another meeting with Mr Barwell yesterday, senior Tory Brexiteers said No were having a second change of heart over the two men.Sir Bernard Jenkin said: “I am assured the Government is still looking at this.“The UK wants a free trade agreement with the European Union. The experts who understand free trade agreements and WTO rules should be included.”In a dig aimed at Mr Robbins and Mrs May’s de facto deputy David Lidington, the Cabinet Office minister, a senior ERG source added: “Some people in Government still want a customs union with the EU.“So it’s no wonder they don’t want the free traders in the room who will explain how it all works”.Meanwhile, a loyal Tory minister accused Tory Brexiteer hardliners of tricking Theresa May by giving her their backing for a orce deal renegotiation.All but one of the -strong ERG voted for the PM’s plan to win legally binding changes to the Irish backstop on Tuesday night.But some of them were accused of already bragging about letting her down to enforce their dream of a no deal hard Brexit.The senior minister told The Sun: “Some of the ERG are now saying their vote means nothing and that whatever changes she gets they won’t vote for the amended deal. Who knew  ”The People’s Vote campaign published new analysis yesterday that suggested many Tory Brexiteers were just using the row over the backstop as an excuse to torpedo Mrs May’s deal.Of the  Tory MPs who voted it down two weeks ago, only  initially objected to the Withdrawal Agreement solely on the basis of the backstop.Most instead complained about how the deal would make the UK a rule-taker, didn’t match the promises of the referendum, or said the “orce bill” was too high.Pro-EU Tory MP Anna Soubry added: “What last night’s votes confirmed is that there is no majority for either a ‘no deal’ Brexit or for the Prime Minister’s original plan – which even Theresa May herself now does not support”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tory meps theresa may brexit delay
story: The PM met them for their last Downing Street meeting on Monday before they leave the European Parliament.An MEP in the meeting said she refused to rule out extending Article .And ministers told MEPs in a separate meeting in Westminster this week that a short extension of a few weeks is likely in order to get key Brexit legislation through Parliament before our exit.But they said they were reassured over her opposition to delaying the process.She told them she was worried that any delay would “undermine public trust in politicians” and would trigger a damaging “loss of democracy”.The Tory MEPs warned that an extension would not only disrupt their own lives but trigger resentment with other EU member states who are taking over Britain’s allocation of MEPs.They said they could just about stomach an extension to July  but any extension beyond that would be “chaotic” because of the European Parliament elections in May.One MEP told The Sun: “We want to get on with our lives and you’re going to cause resentment amongst our colleagues - especiallyyou start messing with their elections, getting involved in elections.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: leavers remainers together uk flourish brexit
story: We all want certainty that we will be leaving the EU on th March.  That would enable us all to plan for le beyond Brexit and lead to a period of political calm.The Government’s deal has been rejected by Parliament.  Therefore, leavers and remainers need to come together to develop a new plan so that we can deliver the referendum result and ensure that we flourish outside the EU.This is exactly what we have tried to do with the help of Kit Malthouse. Nicky Morgan, Robert Buckland and Stephen Hammond were on dferent sides to me and Steve Baker during the referendum.  But we have decided to put our dferences aside and unite to publish a new proposal on how we should leave the EU.Leavers rejected the Government’s EU deal because the backstop would have stopped us from agreeing trade deals. So, we have suggested replacing the backstop with a new protocol that solves the concerns people have about the Irish border and which protects the Union of the United Kingdom.Remainers want a guaranteed Implementation Period – a period which allows us all to adjust to le beyond the EU.  Our plan offers a smooth transition with an additional year of the Implementation Period, making it last until no later than the end of December .Parliament, our country and the  member states of the EU are united in wanting a deal and this proposal can pass through Parliament and restore Government unity, purpose and direction.If the EU ignores this consensus, we have proposed a Plan B – a “triple safety net” to protect us.  It includes cooperation on security, a guarantee by the UK of zero tarfs, no quantitative restrictions and no new trading barriers, along with a generous offer to pay our financial contributions infor an Implementation Period.These proposals would allow everyone to prepare fully for the UK leaving the EU and gives us the space to have proper trade talks so that we can develop a close trading relationship  – which, after all, is what Brexit was supposed to be about.Millions of people voted to leave the EU so that we could become an outward- looking, strong, free-trading nation.They also wanted us to maintain the closest of friendships with our allies on the continent, to continue to trade closely with our European counterparts and to let EU citizens # who have become our friends and neighbours and made the UK their home # feel welcome here.We can still be proud of our shared European heritage after leaving the EU but we must do this as an independent nation.This plan gives us a way of doing this and we invite everyone across the House of Commons and the country to support us as we forge a deal that brings the whole country together.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsBBC Brexit gaffe shows Theresa May travelling to Brussels in World War  planeThe mistake was made on the News at Six, with clips showing planes over the Biggin Hill airbaseShareCommentsByAlex Green:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news offline video bbc-sends-theresa-europe-bomber-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A BBC gaffe appeared to show Theresa May was travelling to Brussels in a fleet of Second World War bombers to reopen negotiations with the EU.During Wednesdays News at Six, footage of planes flying over Biggin Hill airbase was shown as newsreader Sophie Raworth recapped the Prime Ministers visit. The section was meant to be accompanied by footage of Mrs May. Instead, clips showing planes over the air base were shown, comically suggesting Mrs May was travelling to Brussels in a fleet of RAF bombers.  Ms Raworth told viewers: Theresa May says she intends to go back to Brussels to negotiate her Brexit deal but EU leaders say the deal is done and they will not reopen talks.Mrs May said she intends to go back to the EU and reopen negotiation over the Irish backstop but some of the EUs most senior politicians and officials have lined up to insist the deal cannot be unpicked.Paul Royall, who edits the News at Six and News at , said on Twitter the clips had been intended to tease a later story about the airbase.  He joked he was pretty sure Mrs May was not travelling to Europe in this manner. Mr Royall said: For those wondering - simple human error at end of poundBBCNewsSix. A production mistake meant pictures used earlier to tease story about Biggin Hill ended up in our top story recap at close of show. If and when it happens pretty certain PM not travelling to Brussels like this. Best known for its role in the Battle of Britain, Biggin Hill served as one of the vital command bases for the Hurricanes and Spitfires of RAF Fighter Command protecting the south-east.

title: bbc took weeks choose bricks
story: NewsBBC took weeks to choose BRICKS for new EastEnders set as cost spiralled by £mThe surprising admission came as BBC chiefs were quizzed on a staggering £million cost overrun for the new Albert SquareShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video bbc-took-weeks-choose-bricks-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get soaps updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe BBC took weeks to choose bricks for the new EastEnders set, Westminster’s powerful spending watchdog heard tonight. Corporation bosses were hauled before the Commons Public Account Committee to explain a staggering poundmillion cost overrun for the E project, creating the soap’s Albert Square.During the -minute hearing, Labour ’s Chris Evans tackled BBC Content’s chief operating officer Richard Dawkins over specications for the project.Quizzing the broadcasting executive over an apparent delay between the BBC and contractor Wates in selecting raw materials, the MP said: “There seems to be an issue with bricks.” Mr Dawkins confirmed: “Before going into contract, we felt it was important to look at a range of dferent types of brick and, very importantly, bring in our production colleagues to review those bricks themselves given, ultimately, they’re the ones who will be operating the set.  “We did that in advance of letting the contract with Wates. “The objective for the ‘front lot’ is to replicate the existing Albert Square site - making sure we have that right was really important.” In a bizarre exchange which could have come straight from “mockumentary” WA, Mr Dawkins admitted the selection process took “weeks”. Baffled Mr Evans said: “Wouldn’t it have been easier just to go to a DIY shop and compare them ” But the BBC boss hit back: “It’s quite important that we replicate the look and feel of Walford and Albert Square. “It’s Victorian era, it’s an extensive build around the entire Square, so this is really important.”  He insisted: “If you look at the current set there are dferent shades of brick. “This is not just about going and finding off your local DIY store a limited choice. “It was the right thing to do.” The E project to rebuild the soap’s HQ in Elstree, Herts is costing licence fee payers a staggering poundmillion rather than the poundmillion originally planned. It will not be finished until . Mr Evans suggested EastEenders could have followed rival Emmerdale’s example. The ITV soap staged a plane crash two decades ago and revamped its set. “Obviously there’s the example of Emmerdale in the ‘s who flew a fictional aeroplane into... and they wiped out the cast and the set and rebuilt it,” said Mr Evans. “Would it be cheaper through a plot line to have something fall out of the sky fictionally and wipe out the EastEnders set and rebuild it as new ” Lord Hall said: “ I think we are now in WA territory ... but no is the answer.” Asking the peer what lessons the BBC had learned, the MP asked: “Apart from dropping a bomb on the set, what would you dferently ” Lord Hall said: “I think we have got the right team together but leadership is important.” He also blamed the discovery of asbestos for the spiralling cost.

title: brexit backstop what people irish
story: NewsBrexit backstop: What people on the Irish border really think - and fearBrian Reade discovers the Brexit reality at the Irish border - where the backstop stopsShareCommentsByBrian Reade:,  JAN NewsBrian Reade visited the border between Ireland and Northern Ireland - where towns are haunted by fear ofto The Troubles "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBelow the calm surface, a sense of fear and anger is simmering at the place where the backstop stops. Middletown nestles in the hills of Co Armagh on the border with Ireland’s Co Monaghan. Its name is apt, as it is caught in the middle of a history-defining stand-off between the UK and the EU. While Westminster and Brussels use the prospect of bringing back a hard Irish border as a bargaining chip, in Middleshyshyshytown, as in all communities either side of the -mile iding line, they despair at the posturing and dread the reality.Filling his petrol tank at the CFS garage, which sits over the road from the derelict remains of the old customs hut, retired teacher Roy Todd expressed his exasperation over Prime Minister Theresa May ’s U-turn on the Irish backstop. He said: “Throughout the Brexit campaign, Northern Ireland was completely ignored.“And with weeks to go, even though Brussels have said this border is the key issue, they’re just not listening. They’re just having their own little back-room meetings in la-la land. “The Tories’ only policy in Northern Ireland is appeasing the DUP. They don’t care about the border. And they don’t care that they’re playing with fire. “It’s madness.”   Staff in the garage’s Costcutter shop worry about their futures. Most of their trade comes from the South and they fear it could disappear, as long queues at the border put people off crossing it. It’s the same story at McNally’s off-licence in the centre of Middletown. Owner Adrian McNally has run the shop for  years and gets most of his custom from the South. He admits: “Let’s just say, a hard border would not be good for business. People wouldn’t put themselves through all that hassle again. These politicians need to get this sorted right away.” This is an overwhelmingly Remain area in a strongly Remain part of Britain, despite what the DUP have many believe.  Armagh voted % to % to stay in the EU, while Northern Ireland as a whole voted Remain by % to %. Surveys say support for staying in the EU has now risen to %. The main road sign that tells drivers they are entering Northern Ireland has been defaced so many times that it’s been taken down. In its place are placards put up by protestors, warning: “No Borders. No Barriers. Protest.” Only a few weeks ago Theresa May said that ripping up the Irish backstop would be “an entirely irresponsible thing to do”. Yet, in an attempt to stop her party from splitting, she just has. To some, it looks like the , lives lost in the Troubles don’t matter. During those dark decades, Co Armagh was seen as an IRA support stronghold, earning it the nickname Bandit Country. In Middletown, a British Army barracks was a huge visible presence and customs officials patrolled border crossings. After the  Good Friday Agreement the barracks were torn down, a housing estate put in its place and border crossings became seamless.   All that may be about to change. When a group calling themselves “the IRA” claimed responsibility for a bomb in Derry city two weeks ago, they refershyenced a hard Brexit in their statement. In response, Dublin’s Garda Special Branch are sending extra patrols to the border to combat an expected increase in dissident terror activity. A sense of wariness towards British reporters – which I had not experienced since the days when the only stories we came over here to cover were atrocities – is ing. Most people in Middletown don’t want to talk about the possibility of a upturn in terrorism but a pensioner, who just wanted to be known as Dermot, explained how a hard border could facilitate it. He said: “With a hard border, you have customs huts. Inside them, you have men in unorms that say to some people that they are agents of the British state. “Automatically, you have an easy target. Imagine the security needed to protect them  And who in their right minds would work there again ” Once again the Irish people are caught up in a British political quagmire that is not of their making. Dennis Brennan and his we Mary are from Monaghan town, on the Irish side of the border.  Dennis didn’t pull his punches. He said: “Bringing back a hard border would be a disaster. Pure disaster. We never want to see it again. “It’s been brilliant round here since the Good Friday Agreement. Peaceful. But you have to fearthe border s, so could the Troubles. “These politicians have to come to some agreement. There’s no doubt a hard border would be terrible for the Irish economy, but it could be even worse for the people. And surely nobody, but nobody, wants that.”

title: brexit major companies leaving uk
story: NewsBrexit: All the major companies leaving the UK to avoid chaos as the clock ticks downThe British Chambers of Commerce has warned that the preparations by its members so far only represented the “tip of the iceberg”ShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsTheresa May on a visit to a factory"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFor many months the idea that businesses might leave the UK because of Brexit was dismissed as project fear. But as the days to Brexit tick down, more and more companies are choosing to move their headquarters, move jobs or leave the UK altogether. The British Chambers of Commerce has warned that the preparations by its members so far only represented the “tip of the iceberg” and that many of its , members were already spending funds to prepare for a no deal exit.Banks and financial services are worried that a disorderly Brexit could see banks lose passporting rights that allow direct access to clients in the EU. Labour MP Yvette Cooper told the Observer two major employers in her West Yorkshire constituency - luxury goods manufacturer Burberry and confectioner Haribo - had both written to her, warning of the damaging effects of no deal on their UK operations. Burberry employs  people in Castleford, and Haribo  across her constituency.Accountancy firm KPMG reports that many of the businesses they have spoken to are praying for an extension to article .   Companies moving their HQ out of the UK or opening new branches in Europe: Unilever The consumer goods giant was almost first out of the starting gate when it came to making a move. It chose Rotterdam over London for its headquarters but insisted that the move was not due to Brexit. The Anglo-Dutch company was former in the s when Dutch margarine firm Unie merged with British soap maker Lever Brothers.  Despite personally supporting Brexit, James Dyson revealed that he is moving the HQ of his vacuum-cleaner firm to Singapore. The move means Dyson is no longer a British registered company and Singapore will become its main tax base. It is the second blow Dyson has dealt to Brexit Britain after last years announcement that it will manufacturer its new electric cars in Singapore, rather than the UK. The tycoon was one of the few businessmen to back Brexit and has now been accused of staggering hypocrisy. Easyjet Easyjet also made an early move. It has set up a new company in Austria to protect its European business after Brexit. The new airline, EasyJet Europe, will be based in Vienna. The airline must have an air operator certicate in an EU member country to allow it to continue flying between member states after Brexit. Sony  Sony confirmed it is moving its European headquarters from London to Amsterdam. But it insisted that it would not move personnel and operations from the existing UK operations. It is just the latest Japanese company to talk of moves to the continent.   Lloyds of London Insurance and reinsurance market Lloyds of London announced in May that it had received regulatory approval from the National Bank of Belgium to establish an insurance company in Brussels. Those threatening to go: Airbus  Chief executive Tom Enders issued a naked threat to leave the UK by warning it was madness to assume the firm will stay. In a direct warning to the government he said: If theres a no-deal Brexit, we at Airbus will have to make potentially very harmful decisions for the UK. Aerospace is Europes largest aerospace manufacturer, which employs , people in the UK and supports another , through supply chains.   Muji Japanese retailer Muji isrumoured to be moving its European HQ from the UK to Germany. Those who have moved jobs out of the UK: HSBC  The bank has said it is on course to move up to , jobs to France. Goldman Sachs The bank - which employs , UK staff - is set to at least double its Frankfurt workforce to . Barclays The bank expects a small number of roles to move from London to Europe, with most heading to Dublin. Those who have reduced production: Toyota   The car maker has warned that a no-deal Brexit would put production of poundm worth of cars a day at risk. The company has said it would put its Deeside and Burnaston plants on “stop-start” production for weeks or months, putting jobs and wages in jeopardy.   Honda The company has planned a six day halt in April to plan for all possible outcomes caused by logistics and border issues. And other Brexit consequences: Bentley The chief executive of Bentley said the company was stockpiling parts. He described Brexit as a “killer” threatening the profitability of the luxury carmaker. PO  The ferry company announced that its fleet of cross-Channel ferries will be re-registered under the Cypriot flag .The company said they were taking the decision ahead of Britains departure to keeptax arrangements in the EU. It will also mean fewer inspections and delays.

title: brexit what happens now after
story: NewsAnalysisBrexit: What happens now after EU chiefs reject Theresa Mays new planBrussels chiefs said "No, Non, Nein" to Theresa Mays new Brexit plan - so here is what happens nextShareByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  JAN NewsAnalysisThe Prime Minister met a wall of resistance from the EU’s top politicians "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrussels chiefs have lined up today to say “No, Non, Nein” to Theresa May’s bid to reopen the Brexit deal. The Prime Minister met a wall of resistance from the EU’s top politicians who insisted the withdrawal agreement could not be unpicked. Senior figures in Brussels, Berlin, Paris and Dublin all warned that her demand increased the chances of no-deal Brexit as the clock ticks down towards March . Mrs May has admitted there is “little appetite” for reopening a deal in EU capitals, but has been instructed by MPs to try to strike a Plan B. She is desperately trying to hold together a fragile truce in the Tory ranks after a vote on Tuesday demanded the hated Irish backstop was replaced with “alternative arrangements”. So where do things go from here  Weve spoken to sources who are plotting the way forward.  The PM and her ministers will spend the next few days working out exactly what to take back to Brussels. Mrs May has already held talks with Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, Irish PM Leo Varadker and EU chief Donald Tusk. She will now try to nail down the detail of her Plan B. Some Tory MPs thought the Brady amendment just meant a few tweaks on the Irish border backstop plan. But many Brexiteers only backed it on the understanding she would rip up the withdrawal agreement altogether. She will meet with some of those backbenchers on Thursday. As well as trying to hold together the Tory party’s fragile truce, the also needs to push key EU figures as far as they will go.  Mrs May is expected to jet out to Brussels early next week after, as one No  insider put it, “the howling stops and the dust settles”. Government insiders are not optimistic about their chances of persuading Brussels to reopen the orce deal after EU leaders lined up to say “Non. Nein. Nej.” But they’re keeping their fingers crossed that the EU might have one last big compromise up its sleeve. Even the PM admitted it would be a big ask. But in order to deliver on Parliament’s wishesshe has to at least try. She is looking at three areas for the backstop - technological solutions, a time limit and a unilateral exit clause - all of which she has said would be impossible in the past.  The Government has promised thatit gets a deal, MPs will get a second ‘meaningful vote’ on her revised Brexit plan as soon as possible. If, as expected, Brussels rejects her pleas and she comes home empty handed, they will be given a fresh chance to debate Brexit on February  with a vote the next day. This will give MPs the chance to re-run this week’s amendmentsthey wish - potentially handing back control of the Brexit process to Parliament, delaying the UK’s departure beyond March  or legally ruling out crashing out altogether. Mrs May promised another set of votes - which she hopes will not turn into a Valentines’ Day massacre - to stave off a Remainer rebellion on Tuesday. WHAT NOW FOR BREXIT   Unless Brussels puts a last minute offer on the table, which looks unlikely, Mrs May will be back at the despatch box in two weeks’ time. Her party will be more ided than ever. Tory Brexiteers and the DUP will be pushing her to the next stage of the ‘Malthouse compromise’ which would ultimately mean leaving the EU a year later and on damaging WTO terms. Her Remainer MPs who stuck by her this time will be in no mood for standing quietly by. They will push her towards a softer Brexit - working with Labour MPs to get a deal that Brussels would accept. After years of kicking decisions down the road, it will finally be decision day for the PM - continue to appease her hardline Brexiteers, or work across the Commons in the national interest, but risk splitting her party.

title: sajid javids asbo style powers
story: NewsSajid Javids Asbo-style powers to tackle kne crime slammed by campaignersThe Home Secretarys measures include ious options such as limiting suspects’ use of social media in a bid to stop gang rivalries escalatingShareCommentsByTom PettorLouie SmithBen Glaze:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsSajid Javids Kne Crime Prevention Orders are being unveiled today "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Home Secretary Sajid Javid claims his new measures on kne crime will help tackle the growing menace on our streets, but bereaved parents say he is wrong. His Kne Crime Prevention Orders being unveiled today will have ious options such as limiting suspects’ use of social media in a bid to stop gang rivalries escalating. The Asbo-style powers could be used to target those as young as  who police think routinely carry a blade. But officers and campaigners question how the plans can work and say the Government should stop “meddling” so police can get on with the job of enforcing the current laws.  Barry Mizen, whose -year-old son Jimmy was murdered in  in South East London, said: “They are giving the impression new laws will solve the problem asyou can control everything through legislation. “We need more connected communities and support.” Ann Oakes-Odger, who runs charity KneCrime.Org after her son Westley Odger was stabbed to death aged  in Colchester, Essex, in , said: “I feel frustrated that we keep seeing the Home Office meddling with sentencing... “Courts can hand down a four-year jail sentence for someone carrying a kne. “We have to use existing punishments rather than keep bringing in new initiatives. We are not using what we have, why would this work any better ”  Patsy McKie, whose son Dorrie was murdered aged  in Manchester in , said: “Are they going to stop everybody of a certain age to make sure they are not carrying knives How is it going to be carried out on the streets  I don’t knowthey have stopped to think about this properly.” The measures could include banning contact with specic people online. They are civil orders but breaches would be a criminal offence that could result in two years in jail. Like with an Asbo – a court order meant to curb the actions of someone thought likely to cause harm or distress to others – police would apply for these new measures in the courts. They would last for a maximum of two years. The Home Office said the orders could include curfews and geographical restrictions, and force people to attend kne crime awareness courses. Mr Javid said: “I will do everything in my power to tackle the senseless violence that is claiming too many young lives.  “The police already have a range of measures to keep our streets safe, but there is more we can do to help them... “I have listened to their calls and will be introducing these new orders to stop gang members carrying knives in the first place.” Ministers have come under pressure amid a surge in fatal stabbings. Shadow Home Secretary Diane Abbott said: “The Tories’ approach of more laws without the police to enforce them is pointless politicking.” Ministers will seek to amend the Offensive Weapons Bill to introduce the new orders. But Police Federation chairman John Apter said: “The Government is tinkering around the edges...While I cannot fault Mr Javid’s intentions, I don’t hold out much hope these measures will have the dramatic impact... he’s hoping they will.”

title: theresa mays brexit victory not
story: NewsopinionTheresa Mays Brexit victory is not quite what you thinkSanity is beginning to reassert itself, in the place where dreams meet geographyShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  JAN Newsopinion"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Hooray and huzzah, hang out the bunting and issue high-fives all round. Something has finally happened on Brexit.What has happened is that the Tories have agreed to stop screaming up their own bumholes and scream at the EU instead. This will come as a relief to all those who witnessed their -month act of circular self-abuse, but they did at least give us a new definition for windbags.  This has been described as Theresa Mays best day at work since  by all those people who have not had enough fresh air recently. Her great success is that someone  has been able to unite the Tories around a version of Brexit that is impossible, impractical and undeliverable.They even managed to persuade  of the crazier members of the Labour Party to join them in this unmedicated dreamland, where the DUP have long gambolled in the insane belief it will reignite their holy war against the Fenians.The Tories have, for the first time in two and a half years, decided what they want. The problem is that it is the opposite of what Theresa has done or can do. On November , , she told the House of Commons: The Brexit talks are about acting in the national interest, and that means making what I believe to be the right choices, not the easy ones.I know there are some who have said I should simply rip up the UK’s commitment to a backstop, but this would have been an entirelyirresponsible course of action. It would have meant reneging on a promise made to the people of Northern Ireland during the referendum campaign and afterwards - that under no circumstances would Brexit lead to ato the borders of the past - and it would have made it impossible to deliver a withdrawal agreement.As Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, I have a responsibility to people in every part of our country, and I intend to honour that promise.And last night, she was told to do all the things she didnt want to do on the grounds that doing them would be f***ing disastrous. What has happened is this: . Theresa presented Plan A, which guaranteed the rights and safety of .m British citizens in Northern Ireland, and was punched in the face by Parliament which snarled stuff em.. Theresa presented Plan B, which was much the same but had a dferent letter on the front page, and Parliament said well maybe so long as we can decide to say stuff em later, slapped Theresa lightly and sent her back to Brussels. The EU are about to say alors, but you people cest tres thick. Theresas people are already briefing therell be a Plan C. And I can tell you now whats in it.  Plan C will have moved on signicantly from Plan B by being more like Plan A. Itll have the same words in much the same order, with very similar promises about protecting those .m British citizens with a backstop, and it will get voted through by Parliament for two reasons.First, theyve voted on it twice already, and have been dragged towards accepting a version of it. On the third time of asking, theyll be ready to back ANY version, in much the same way a man who has kicked himself in the head will wonderits possible to do it again.Imagine such a person, and you will have invented Iain Duncan Smith.  Secondly, there will be no other option.There is now no Parliamentary time left for Theresas deal to get the necessary legislation through before its self-imposed Article  deadline. There isnt even enough time for the new laws we need to trade under WTO rules in the event of a No Deal Brexit.By automatic operation of the law, on March  all EU treaties cease to be effective. Predicted results include motorways turning into lorry parks, medicines being rationed, the imposition of martial law and Jacob Rees-Mogg declaring an ancestral right to eat peasants. Even those Parliamentarians whove been hoarding gold and have a Barbudan bolthole dont want that sort of legacy hung around their neck, so extending the deadline is inevitable. And fortunately, the law they wrote about all this allows for a minister to change the exit date whenever they fancy. And most importantly there is no other option for the border in Northern Ireland. No way to take back control, no way to superimpose a UK referendum on to a people who had a referendum on this already, and managed a % mandate on an % turnout. People traffickers and drug smugglers dont fill in customs forms, weve no way to police a -mile border with  crossing points, and as the cherry on the cake elderly IRA bombers are coming out of retirement to make car bombs for new splinter groups.The only way all these things were resolved was with an open border, that allowed the unionists to remain British while allowing the republicans to pretend they were Irish.No-one has an alternative to that, and it is a fact of quite beautul irony that the only way anyones going to Brexit isthey refuse to take back control of our sole land border with the EU.So we wont Brexit on March , because we cant. Well call it Brexit a bit later, and it wont be because all this arguing was just to get us to the point where we could discuss what Brexit will look like. And it wont ever BE Brexit, because every power-crazed demand the backbench fruitloops have made has had to be dropped - when courts ruled it unlawful, when public opinion swung against them, and when Theresa persisted them into submission.Her problem is that all the Brexit chaos has been laid at her door. She has been blamed for the indecision, poor negotiation and infighting, for a dud election and international humiliation.Yet somehow, through either great stupidity or brilliant stratagem, she has forced her party and the country to agree what it never would have done in , a year or even  months ago. Leavers and Remainers now fervently believe any deal is better than none at all, appreciate Northern Irelands problems in a way few ever bothered to do, andthe polls are right are coming to the opinion that the current deal we have with the EU is the best of all possible worlds.What happened last night is that the hardliners have taken their latest of , tiny steps towards admitting their dream is just that. Thats why Theresa is stronger than ever, why the Labour Party is on the back foot and the EU is scratching its head.Sanity is beginning to reassert itself. It says do something, avert disaster, extract cranium from bum, ask yourselfthis is a good idea. All those Parliamentarians who complained Parliament was being undemocratic are now praising it for embodying the will of the people.Theres months and probably years more of arseing about, of course, and any group of people with a fetish for rectal screaming are probably going to try it a few times more before they realise it hurts too much.Sanity is not immediate. But it is there, flickering gently in the place where dreams meet geography.
