title: marks  spencers new wrap
story: NewsMarks  Spencers new wrap branded abomination by outraged chefsMS have come under fire from food fans and chefs for a new biryani plant-based wrap theyre sellingShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  JAN NewsChefs are not happy about MSs new vegan wrap "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email If theres one thing that people can be particularly precious about, its food - and for good reason.Delicious food can be hard to find as its so easy to make a dish thats lacking in quality, so when you find something that tastes amazing, youll probably want to protect it at all costs.One thing that people are particularly feeling protective of right now, is biryani, and its all because of Marks  Spencer.The retailer has come under fire from Indian chefs for selling a sweet potato biryani wrap as part of their new plant-based vegan range.   The wrap, which costs pound. has been criticised for lacking rice, meat and fish as well as being served in a flat bread.Chef Maunika Gowardhanm, author of Indian Kitchen, shared a snap of the wrap on Twitter , saying: Thanks but I like my biryani with rice in a bowl not a wrap. Seriously MS! She added: Just to put it in perspective, in India firstly there is no such thing as a veg biryani. Most places will serve mutton or chicken or even fish. Its wrong on many levels when people will assume this is what a biryani looks like! Biryani needs rice, isnt stuffed in bread and doesnt include lettuce.   More than  people liked her tweet, with many taking the time to share their thoughts. One person replied: OMG a complete abomination and wrong on every single level. SO tired of all these brands and supermarkets plundering and murdering other people’s cuisines. Genuinely should be illegal. Another commented: Im on hold to the police. A third added: Eurgh! What were they thinking    Darjeeling Express, a Soho-based Indian restaurant, also shared their disgust about the wrap. They wrote: This is wrong at SO many levels - who are you paying to design your wraps @marksandspencer  You seriously need to rethink your exotic wrap selection. That is not biryani - you do not appropriate names from a cuisine without even bothering to do any research. However not everyone was opposed to trying the new MS offering.   A dferent Twitter user posted: I tried one, not bad but not enough spice. As a veggie its nice to find a sandwich I can buy when in a hurry.Meanwhile, Chef Vivek Singh, of Cinnamon Club, London, told The Times people accusing MS of cultural appropriation should loosen up.He continued: People in Britain love biryani as much as most of us from the sub-continent. Having cooked professionally for  years, I think a vegetarian biryani is just as authentic as anything . Responding to the backlash, a spokesperson for Marks  Spencer said: MS is famous for its food innovation and our developers use a fusion of dferent flavours and ingredients to create an exciting range of products to appeal to customers tastes.

story: NewsNew study reveals what workers want most from their employersMore than half also want their staff benefits to help improve their work-le balanceShareCommentsByEmma Elsworthy:,  JAN NewsAccess to mental health care is also important to those who started working this decade "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFlexible working hours, more pension contributions – and extra holiday for long service are among the top work perks British employees want, according to a survey. A study of , workers found more than half want their staff benefits to help improve their work le balance and  per cent want added extras which will save them money. And while younger adults highlight the need for help with housing, older generations are more concerned with private healthcare. Access to mental health care is also more important to those who started working this decade than to those who began their careers in any decade before.   It also emerged fewer than one in five are currently totally satisfied with the benefits package provided by their employer. And half of employees would leave their current employmentthey thought they could get a position where with more perks, with just  per cent preferring extra pay over comprehensive benefits. Steven Osei, spokesman for the Preferential Partnerships programme at Get Living, said: It’s no surprise that employees’ attitudes to workplace benefits have changed over the last five decades since the world we live in is almost unrecognisable now. “Employees are moving jobs more often, increasingly working from home and expecting to be compensated for their dedication. “To keep up with the competition, employers need to reflect workers more flexible lestyles.” The study also revealed employees who started their working le in  or later are most likely to want pets in the office, and free breakfast supplies. And the demand for company-expensed dental care has decreased over the decades, with nearly a quarter of older workers feeling it should be offered as standard by employers. This compares to just nine per cent of people who started their careers during this decade. Free tea and coffee is most valued by workers aged between -, with over-s the most likely to seek out an enhanced pension contribution.   People aged between - cite unlimited holiday days as the most attractive perk they think a company could offer. It also emerged employees who have been working the longest are most satisfied with their current benefits package, with those starting work in the s the least happy. Earlier this week he announced plans to abandon a legal battle to maintain an injunction against a newspaper from publishing the claims. He wants his cake and to eat it.” The High Court this week heard that Green’s lawyers had sent a hand-delivered letter to a witness, to threaten her to stay silent.The tycoon is also said to have sent “intimidating” letters to alleged victims, against speaking out. title: schoolboy 13 kicked neck vicious
story: NewsSchoolboy, , kicked in neck by vicious bullies says I might as well kill myselfDanial Elliott, from Beverley, East Yorkshire, initially hid his injuries from his worried mum Vikki who says her son threatened to hang himself before ChristmasShareCommentsByAlex GroveBradley Jolly:,  JAN NewsDanial Elliott, , was taken to hospital after the attack"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A -year-old boy said he might as well kill himself after vicious bullies ambushed and attacked him in a sickening street attack. Danial Elliott was beaten up as he walked home from school last Thursday. The youngster was hit from behind and kicked in the back and neck by his attackers who then fled the scene, Hull Live says.The schoolboy initially hid his injuries from his worried mum Vikki Elliott until they got back home. But the stress of his attack alongside being repeatedly bulled at school led to him later threaten serious self-harm. Ms Elliott, from Beverley, East Yorkshire, said: He looked fine when he got into the car. He said nothing to me which is not unusual and because of the bullying he will dust himself off as he is the eldest sibling.   We got into the house and he was stomping about I was asking what was wrong. He got into a bit of a confrontation with me before going into the hallway, putting his hands on his head and dragging his nails into his own face. He then shouted I might as well kill myself. The mum-to-four, , said Danial has been bullied since primary school, with children targeting him because of his bowel problems. She added: They call him things like smelly, a toilet, they call him all sorts. He doesn’t tell me anything now because he just gets fed up with repeating it.   It’s getting to the point where they are bullying him that badly that he doesn’t want to be around here anymore and before Christmas he threatened to hang himself. We are keeping an eye on him but there is nothing we can do to help him with this condition he has got. He is on medication andit stops working we have to up the dosage. He sees doctors and paediatricians but there is nothing  we can do until he is older. After the attack, Danial ended up in hospital until am on Friday, January , and he had to have his head put in a neck brace for extra protection. They could have killed him, Ms Elliott said. One kick in the wrong place could have broken his neck or paralysed him and the people who did this need to understand that.  You hear about it all the time – one punch in the wrong place and you can kill someone. They could have left me without my son and his three younger siblings without a brother and that is just devastating to think about. They were so worried on Thursday when he was in hospital and losing Danial would have left a big whole in our family.The incident has been reported to Humberside Police but it cannot be confirmed whether Danial was attacked by the same bullies who have been making his le hell at school.His mum continued: He is not ready to go back to school. He is so withdrawn and becomes even more withdrawn when school is mentioned. He is in a lot of pain and I want to doctors to write a note so that the school knows he needs time to recuperate. story: NewsStaffie fans defend pets against vicious label as dog declared UKs favouriteStaffie owners are delighted that ITVs survey on Britains favourite breed challenges misconceptions about the dogsShareCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsThere are lots of misconceptions about the breed "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain is undoubtedly a nation of dog lovers, and many of us were delighted as Staffordshire Bull Terriers were announced as the UKs favourite breed yesterday. ITV carried out a survey of , people to determine which is Britains favourite breed, and the beloved Staffie was officially declared the top dog.The vast majority of Mirror readers reacting to the story on Facebook were pleased the breed is finally getting positive recognition, with many applauding the pups loyal, loving and soft nature that make them great family pets.Some Twitter users were keen to debunk the dogs bad rep in light of the news, posting adorable snaps of their dangerous and vicious pooches. Last year  Staffies and Staffie crosses were adopted across the Dogs Trusts network of rehoming centres. We see first-hand the positive dference these dogs make to their owners lives, sowe were delighted to see this breed crowned as the nations favourite, Dogs Trust added.We hope this boost for Staffies will encourage people to embrace the affectionate and loyal qualities that we know are so true of the breed. title: google doodle celebrates malaysian dish
story: NewsGoogle Doodle celebrates the Malaysian dish Nasi lemak - but what is it The spicy concoction is considered to be Malaysias national dishShareCommentsByLuke Kenton:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror tech video google-celebrates-nasi-lemak-animated-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Nasi lemak, a popular Malaysian delicacy, is being celebrated with a Google Doodle today.The flavoursome and spicy concoction is considered to be the country’s national meal and is often eaten for breakfast by most Malaysians. Translating to mean “rich rice”, the dish’s main component consists of rice cooked in coconut milk, along with panda leaf and galangal root flavouring. A number of ingredients can then be added to the mixture. The most popular of which are usually crispy peanuts, anchovies, sliced cucumber and hard-boiled eggs.  Topped with samba hot sauce or tamarind juice, the rich rice is often served with fried chicken or beef rendang on the side. Its then served in a banana leaf - or bungkus - to keep it warm. Nasi lemak is regarded as being hugely signicant to the culture of the south-east Asian country. It’s thought to have been invented on the west coast of Peninsular Malaysia, intended the be a filling breakfast for farmers and labourers. But sold at roadside stalls and markets, the meal is so fervently popular it’s regularly eaten for lunch and dinner as well.  A famous legend says the recipe was discovered by accident when Seri, the daughter of a widow called Mak Kuntum, accidentally spilled coconut milk into a pot of rice she was cooking. “What did you cook ,” Mak allegedly asked. “Nasi le, Mak!,”responded Seri. Many iations of Nasi lemak have been developed over the years. It’s now garnered a cult appeal across India and China as well.

title: brexit dundee chiefs prepare for martial law empty shelves no fuel and food rationing if there is no deal
story: Dundee chiefs are preparing for the prospect of martial law, empty supermarket shelves, no fuel and food rationing in a “worst case scenario” no-deal Brexit.Such is the concern at the impact on the city and residents that possible emergency measures are already being put in place.Dundee City Council, along with other organisations including Dundee and Angus Chamber of Commerce, revealed the work being done to protect provisions in the city should Britain tumble out of the EU without a trade deal.Councillor Will Dawson is heading the local authority group that is preparing for the worst possible scenarios.He said this could include food and fuel being stockpiled and rationing implemented. vw, px"   vw, px"  Mr Dawson said: “We have no definite or accurate prediction of what could happen but what we are doing is preparing for everything and anything.“We have to be prepared for the ‘what  ’ scenario. Rationing and martial law, along with stock piling of food and fuel are among the options we will need to consider. Whatthe fuel runs out  Whatthe medicine runs out  Whatfood can’t get through the ports  WhatEU residents just go home “During a meeting at Cosla last week, it was clear from the discussions that a lot of time and effort is going into these preparations which go from the sublime to the ridiculous. However, we need to ensure that no matter what happens, our city and our country can keep running.“Most of these preparations are being done nationally so there is no fuel or food stockpile in Dundee as such. However, we do know how much fuel that we have and what scenarios could lead to rationing and blue light only situations.”The council’s Labour group leader Kevin Keenan said: “There are resilience teams working on Dundee’s worst case scenario. It is fair to say that in the work they are undertaking, they are considering there could be shortages of foods and fuel. I would not like to set panic out there, but it’s right for this work to be carried out.“We hear from the haulage industry that delays at ports are a high possibility resulting in a delay for foods being delivered to shops. I hope supermarkets are planning for that level of delay.“Other businesses in the city that run a ‘just in time’ manufacture should seriously look at the products that may affect them and build some level of resilience into their purchasing regime until things settle down.”Alison Henderson , CEO of Dundee and Angus Chamber of Commerce, said: “Brexit’s implications for business and the wider community will bring change for businesses of every size and sector.“We believe all firms – not just those directly and immediately affected – should be undertaking a Brexit ‘health check’, and a broader test of existing business plans.” vw, px"  Cabinet secretary Sir Mark Sedwill denied soldiers would be put on the streets in event of a no deal Brexit. He noted the civil contingencies department – which has the powers to declare a “national emergency” – has been involved in no deal planning.If an “emergency” is declared, the armed forces can be deployeddeemed necessary.

title: dundee people tayside youngsters to play for scotland at maiden powerchair football tournament
story: Four local disability athletes have been called up to the nine-strong Scotland squad which will take part in the nation’s first-ever powerchair football tournament.Tayside Dynamos quartet Eythan Galloway, Logan Mitchelson, Kein Speed and Nicky Duncan will turn out for the Scots in the Duncan Scales Memorial Cup next weekend.Taking place at the University of Leeds, Galloway , Mitchelson , Speedand Duncanwill line-up for Scotland as their two teams go up against Leeds Chariots, Electric Eels and Leeds Dynamos this Sunday.It is a historic occasion for the sport in Scotland, which allows those who need to use a powerchair to get around to take part in organised football, and the team have been preparing accordingly.They recently faced a tough test against Middlesbrough Powerchair Football Club, the nation’s maiden game, with Galloway the scorer of Scotland’s only goal in a - defeat.Despite the loss, it was a great moment for all concerned and Angus native Galloway was delighted to be involved, let alone score.“It’s was a huge honour to be picked to play for my country,” he said.“Being the youngest player in the squad, I didn’t expect to be picked to play in the actual game.“So to score the first-ever goal for Scotland was like a dream come true.”Powerchair football is the fastest-growing disability sport in the UK with  players registered to play with the Scottish Powerchair Football Assocation .Tayside Dynamos take part in the Muscular Dystrophy UKScottish Premiership with the likes of Galloway starring.The sport is fast-paced and dynamic and allows all ages, disabilities and genders to compete alongside together.It is a four-a-side game played on a basketball-sized court with most players having conditions such as cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophy and spina bidaSPFA chairperson Willie Pettigrew is delighted to see the level of inclusion and sporting progress being made as Scotland prepares to host its first, as yet unnamed, international tournament in Largs next year.He said: “This is another exciting step for powerchair football in Scotland.“Travelling down to Leeds will give us an opportunity to show what we’ve learned from playing Middlesbrough as we build towards hosting an international tournament in .“There’s a range of involvement with players as young as  and -years-old right up  and -year-olds. There are two leagues in Scotland – the Premiership and the Championship – with opportunities for people to play at any level they can.“This includes right up to the Scotland team – Tayside Dynamos and their rivals in the Premiership Clyde Alba are a huge part of the national team set-up.“They are the main clubs and provide a lot of the players.“The support from our partners at the SFA Para Football Association, Mobility Central Sport and Muscular Dystrophy UK has been invaluable.”

title: greggs have nailed it tele readers put new vegan sausage roll to the test
story: The humble sausage roll – meat or murder Ask a meat-eater for their take on the baked treat and they’ll tell you it’s a staple of weekend treats or of school lunches in times gone by.It’s an unshakeable formula – meat, layers of pastry, glazed with milk or egg and baked until golden. Delish – or is it Bakery chain Greggs attracted both praise and outrage when it announced it was introducing a vegan-friendly sausage roll.The snack is made with a “bespoke” Quorn filling and wrapped layers of pastry which are glazed with vegetable oil.With no meat at its core and no glaze of milk or egg, it couldn’t be further from the traditional idea of the sausage roll.But is it time we rethought the unpresuming tasty treat To solve the country’s most important conundrum – never mind Brexit – the Tele took to the streets to put Greggs’ latest creation to a blind taste test.Equipped with both meaty and vegan ieties, we gave locals one or the other and asked them to guess which they had just eaten.No points, no prizes – but we did give them free food.Stobswell retail worker Ali Fenton, , correctly guessed we had given her a vegan roll.She said: “It’s pretty good. I’m not really a big sausage roll fan but to be honest you wouldn’t be able to tell the vegan one is any dferent.“I can just tell they’re dferent because of the texture.“It’s nice for people who are either allergic or make the choice to have more options available – especially among the bigger companies.”Kat Marshall, , knew which one she had been given – as she had a vegan sausage roll in Glasgow last week.“To be honest, Greggs have nailed it,” she said.“I’m not a massive meat eater but I’m trying to be more mindful of what I eat. It’s nice to have the option.”In Dundee, there are all kinds of places where people can get their plant-based fix, from local businesses such as Marwick’s and Avery  Co to big chains such as Pizza Hut and Nando’s.Andthe experts have their way, we’ll all be eating less meat in future – and not necessarily for the sake of the animals.A report published by food researchers the EAT-Lancet Commission suggests meat-eaters need to cut consumption to the equivalent of half a rasher of bacon a day.If we don’t all adopt “planetary health” diets with less meat and more veg, it suggests the world could be irreversibly damaged due to the environmental impact of producing meat.It warned: “Without action, today’s children will inherit a planet that has been severely degraded and where much of the population will increasingly suffer from malnutrition and preventable disease.”Our other two tasters, Anis Makesh and Jamie Duggan, said they could easily make the switch for the sake of the planet.Jamie, , said: “I quite like a sausage roll and I would give the vegan one eight out of .“I can’t tell that this is a vegan one – I would probably say I could make the switch as long as things are the same price.”Anis, from the city centre, scored the veggie version seven out of .He said: “It’s very good. You can feel it’s a bit dferent but not all that much. If this sort of thing is widely available and it’s tasty, I could eat less meat.”So the humble sausage roll might be changing – but our test suggests it’s not all bad. And making small changes like this could help to preserve it – and the planet – for years to come.

title: ivan golac returning to dundee united for hall of fame induction

title: jesse curran to miss dundees scottish cup replay at queen of the south
story: Midfielder Jesse Curran will miss Dundee’s Scottish Cup replay at Queen of the South today because of the hamstring injury he suffered in Saturday’s defeat against Motherwell.The Dark Blues are assessing the problem that saw Curran pull up with just five minutes on the clock at Dens Park.However, the fear is the Australian, who was limping heavily as he headed for the dressing-room after watching the first half from the bench, could be sidelined for several weeks.That would be a major blow for both boss Jim McIntyre and the -year-old who has made  appearances in an excellent first campaign as a top-team regular.Curran’s form has seen him monitored by his home country’s national team while Philippines manager Sven-Goran Eriksson has offered him the chance to be part of their set-up.He qualies for them through his mother and is also eligible for Scotland, where his father was born.“The physio is assessing Jesse and we’ll just have to see how he is,” said his club boss.Jim was left frustrated by the single-goal defeat against ’Well that came courtesy of a second-half penalty from David Turnbull, following a rash Ryan Inniss tackle on Elliot Frear.The gaffer, though, took consolation from the way his side dominated most of the play.“To say it was frustrating is stating the obvious because we put so much into the game. We didn’t deserve to lose that game, in my opinion we deserved to win it,” he said.“But we didn’t punish Motherwell in the first half when we were on top and paid the price for a bad decision in our own penalty box.“The big manis honest enough to put his hands up because there was no need to go to ground. title: new plans for cook school and cafe at dundee butchers
story: New plans have been submitted for a cook school and cafe at a Dundee butchers.Scott Brothers Butchers initially submitted the application in September of last year but had to make adjustments to the ventilation system.If given the go-ahead, the new cafe will be located above the butchers shop on Nethergate, with the cook school on the top floor.Scott Brothers co-owner Scott Jarron said: “We’re just waiting to hear back from the council about it.“Planning is holding us up a bit. We were planning to start work in February or March but it is not going to be anything like that.“With a bit of luck, the work will start later this year.”Scott said the firm – which has three premises across the city – has been planning the changes for a while.He added: “The cafe is not going to be like a greasy spoon. We’re looking to have good, sustainable food on offer at a reasonable cost.“Our concept is to offer a menu that reflects our core business as butchers and showcases the quality of the produce – cottage pie, burgers, rolls, pies, sandwiches and wraps, as well as a selection of cakes made in our own bakery.”Scott added that he hopes the cook school will educate people on how to cook healthily.He said: “People are getting caught up in ready meals so the basis for the cook school is to promote the importance of using locally-sourced products.“The school will also be available to certain young groups that have not had access to cookery classes so we can teach them the importance of cooking for themselves.“The other element of the cook school will be to offer butchery classes so that people can learn more about our trade, which has played a big part in Dundee’s development.“Young people aren’t educated any more about how to cook but it’s a le skill which needs to be passed on. It doesn’t have to be all about pizzas.“We’re also looking to work with local charities and schools to get people involved in the cook school.”Scott said he doesn’t expect the renovations to last longer than four-six weeks as the shop will need to be closed during the work.There will be a signicant investment injected into the premises for the revamp, expected to be in the region of between £, and £, in total.

title: nothing wrong with it dundee council defends frozen meals plan for schools
story: Dundee City Council has defended its plans to introduce frozen meals into schools.The local authority is proposing to change its school meal provision from cooking on site to cooking meals at a central hub and distributing them frozen to schools.Concerns have been raised by parents who fear that frozen meals will not be a healthy option for their children.Discussing the plans at a meeting of the council’s policy and resources committee, director of children and families services Paul Clancy said: “We are confident there is the same nutritional value in frozen food as in fresh.“We are planning to get as many people as possible to taste the frozen meals before we introduce them to our schools.“That way they will see and taste for themselves the high quality of the food that will be produced. The food will also meet all government guidelines.”Alan Ross, convener of the council’s community safety and public protection committee, said: “There are a lot of misconceptions around frozen food.“There is nothing wrong with frozen food.”Dundee, Angus and Perth and Kinross councils are considering the proposals, with the cuisine centre in Dundee set to undergo a multi-million-pound transformationthe plans are approved.

title: tesco withdraws application to add hand car wash at dundee store
story: Supermarket giant Tesco has withdrawn its application to add a hand car wash to another of its local stores.Waves Consultancy, which operates hand car washes on behalf of Tesco across the country, submitted an application to Dundee City Council in November outlining its plans for the Kingsway store.It wanted to replace nine of the  existing parking spaces with a floodlit concrete “wash pad” to enable the hand-washing of cars on-site.The local authority has confirmed that it considers the application “formally withdrawn”.However, a spokesman for Waves Consultancy said the plans couldin future.He said: “We recently withdrew the planning application on this location.“However we are still looking to expand our portfolio of hand car washes in the area and may resubmit this site in the future.”

title: tom duthie dundee united need to start performing in the big games
story: Despite the major disappointment of the defeat at Ayr United, the consolation for Dundee United fans at the moment has to be the fact they have become genuine promotion contenders under Robbie Neilson.The gap to the top of the table has stretched to six points again because of that Friday night loss at Somerset Park coupled with Ross County’s victory over Alloa on Saturday afternoon.It can’t be forgotten United’s poor goal dference effectively means right now the gap to the top is seven points.With just  games to go, time is also running out for United to make up the lost ground and clinch promotion at the first time of asking.Boosted by the January signings that are set to continue in the final few days of the window,they can gel quickly enough, Neilson will believe the deficit can by clawed back and, in a Championship race that’s seen every team drop points regularly, even a decent winning run could do that.The manager’s overall record since he arrived in October does also give some reason for Arabs not to give up hope just yet.Since his debut win at Partick Thistle in mid-October, with , his team are the leading points gatherers in the second tier.By beating Alloa in Dingwall on Saturday, County took their points tally over the same period to  and while no one would argue the fact promoted Ayr are having an excellent first campaign back at this level, they have been showing signs of running out of steam.Between their hugely impressive - win at Tannadice right at the end of November and their repeat success over United the other night, Ian McCall’s team had gone five league games without a win and also, of course, suffered that humiliating Scottish Cup exit at the hands of juniors Auchinleck Talbot.If that, and the points tally under the new manager, provides encouragement, what continues to be a major concern for United is their poor record against the others at the top end of the table.Friday was their fth clash with the top two on league business and, to date, the record reads played five, lost four, won one, score two and conceded .Add to that a League Cup loss up at County in July and what you have is a worrying statistic.Without wishing to paint an even darker picture, they have also only drawn two clashes with Inverness with both coming when the Highlanders were sitting in one of the promotion play-off places.If they are to realise American owner Mark Ogren’s dream of going up automatically during his first months in charge, it’s a statement of the obvious to say the big-game record has to improve drastically.Should it, United can still get to where they want to be. They’ve two games to come against County and one final crack at Ayr and, of those showdowns, two are at Tannadice.Yes, the two heaviest defeats of the season came there against County and Ayr but under Neilson that second defeat was the only one he’s suffered in seven home games so far.And last time he sent out a team to face County he did mastermind what was without doubt the best win of the campaign to date, a gritty - success on their patch, in November.If the manager can mould his rebuilt team over the next few weeks, wins like that one can be repeated.They’ll have to be, or United’s big-game failures will see them negotiating even more vital outings in the play-offs.

story: A FORMER Culloden Academy pupil who has set up his own care business is to bring new le back to a former tourist office on the A just south of Inverness.Tim Cockinghopes to create up to  new jobs in the care sector and is looking for an operator to run a restaurant cafeacute type business from the former Visit Scotland office at Daviot.Formerly known as the Daviot Woods picnic site he is renaming it the lsquoNorth Gatewayrsquo.ldquoItrsquos right off the A and a perfect location for travellers passing through Inverness perhaps going to do the North Coast , said Mr Cocking who left Culloden when he was  with his family to live in Edinburgh.ldquoIrsquove seen the building when Irsquom visiting the north and itrsquos been looking rather sad and dilapidated and I thought there was something I could do with it.Mr Cockingrsquos Edinburgh-based company Brightcare has now applied to Highland Council for permission to change the use of the building to incorporate restaurant and retail facilities.ldquoThere once were public toilets there and itrsquos my intention to reinstate these once we have a thriving business on the site.His company Brightcare provides private home care for private clients looking for an alternative to residential care and already employs six people in the Highlands.ldquoWe have our HQ in Edinburgh and employ  people Scotland-wide and six of these jobs are in the Inverness area. But it is our intention to grow that business to about  jobs in the next few years.ldquoThe building at Daviot would also have an office for Brightcare. story: Worried parents handed in a -signature online petition to the council today in an effort to save Special Needs Action Project .Later following a meeting between council chief executive Donna Manson, council officers and Snap manager Dawn Walker and Snap board chairman Donald Robertson, the council issued a statement saying it recognises ldquothe very much valued support this organisation provides to families in Inverness.Ms Manson said: ldquoOfficers are continuing dialogue with Snap to identy other possible sources of funding to help achieve a viable position. We will be entering into early discussions with Snap and other third sector organisations regarding need, service requirements and formal processes to allocate funding. There will be a workshop in February with members of the third sector, including SNAP, to agree methods of funding and how we can redesign our processes.She added: ldquoOur discussions have been useful and I have given a clear commitment from the council that we will work with the third sector to help lever funding from where as we work together for the benefit of all Highland communities.Ms Walker said: ldquoWhile the meeting was more positive, we are still in a position of not knowing what is going to happen.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Highland MPs scathing after Prime Minister vows to reopen Brexit backstop negotiations
story: The - vote victory came after Speaker John Bercow selected seven amendments that iously sought to extend the date of departure, make a lsquono-dealrsquo impossible, place the Brexit process in the hands of parliament, and find an alternative to the Northern Ireland back-stop.All were defeated except the Brady Amendment ndash seeking a renegotiated backstop - and a non-binding motion calling for an economically damaging lsquono-dealrsquo to be ruled out.But Theresa May looks set to face a struggle reopening the Withdrawl Agreement negotiated with the EU after European Council president, Donald Tuck, immediately shot down the proposals, stating: "The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation."The SNPrsquos Westminster leader Ian Blackford, who is also MP for Ross, Skye and Lochaber, had earlier submitted an amendment noting how the Scottish and Welsh assemblies voted against the Prime Ministerrsquos deal, calling for an extension of article  ndash which would delay the UKrsquos EU departure - and for no deal to be removed as an option. It was defeated by  votes to .He warned that the development means Number  has brought the country closer to a no-deal Brexit and undermined the Good Friday Agreement that brought peace to Northern Ireland.ldquoBy throwing her weight behind an impossible demand from the hard Brexit wing of the Conservative Party the Prime Minister today demonstrated beyond doubt she is now prepared to take Scotland and the UK over the Brexit clf-edge.ldquoTheresa May could have worked across parties to protect jobs and living standards but she chose to side with the Brexit extremists in her own party.ldquoOnce again Scotland has been silenced, sidelined and shafted by Westminster, and we are paying a heavy price for a chaotic Tory government that Scotland did not vote for. And today the Tories ripped apart the Good Friday agreement, an international treaty the UK had signed up to."His SNP colleague Drew Hendry, who represents Inverness,Nairn,Badenoch and Strathspey, added: ldquoWith her Brexit deal in tatters after its record-breaking defeat in the House of Commons, Theresa Mays focus remains on appeasing her Tory colleagues, rather than on delivering a plan to protect jobs and the economy.ldquoShe knows this fudge on the Irish backstop cannot be delivered in any meaningful way, yet she continues to waste what valuable time is left. It is little wonder the EU  are so bemused by her behaviour.ldquoAs ever, it is the public who will pay the price for this shambles. The Prime Minister has made no attempt to recognise the views of the Scottish electorate, and the damage Brexit will cause to the Scottish economy.ldquoLabour has shown they are also not to be trusted, leaving us facing the prospect of being hauled out of the EU and made to endure all the damage that brings. It is clear Westminster is not working for Scotland and its time to take ownership of our own future.The Liberal Democrats voted in favour of the Labour MP Yvette Cooperrsquos amendment which was defeated by  votes to . It sought more to allow parliament more time to figure out how to break the deadlock.When this failed Liberal Democrat MP Jamie Stone, who represents Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross,argued for a Peoplersquos Vote because crashing out with no-deal would, he said, be a disaster for those in the far north.ldquoJobs, infrastructure, health care in my constituency all rely on EU citizens to fill vital roles and on EU funding," he explained.ldquoMPs who voted in favour of Bradyrsquos amendment were knowingly voting for a no deal Brexit. The EU had made it very clear to all involved that they would not reopen negotiations. These MPs are running after a fantasy and itrsquos British people who will pay the price.ldquoAll Theresa May has done is kick the can down the road and run the clock down even further. She is gambling with time we just donrsquot have.Mr Stone also sought to underline the importance of the non-binding Spelman amendment which stated the UK will not leave the EU without a deal.ldquoLabour MPs who sat on their hands have once again facilitated Theresa May and the European Research Groupin their pursuit of a no deal Brexit.ldquoA win for amendment ldquoI means the government has once again been told that there is no majority in the house for a no deal Brexit. The PM needs to take no deal off the table - as she should have done months ago - and recognise that people are not in favour of a hard Brexit which will damage our country.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Inverness Airport hotel plan takes off
story: The Courtyard by Marriot will be situated within Inverness Airport Business Park and it set to open its doors later this year.Owned and developed by Molo Hotels, the property will be operated by the independent hotel management company RBH.Chief business development officer at RBH, Andrew Robb, said the company is delighted to be working alongside Molo hotels and Polcom Construction for the project.ldquoWersquove forged a strong working relationship with Molo Hotels and Polocom Construction over the years and are thrilled to be working with them on what promises to be another outstanding property, said Mr Robb.The -bedroom hotel plans include meeting and fitness facilities as well as a bar and bistro.Contractor Polocom Construction has started the production of bedrooms in Poland before they are transported to the site near Inverness airport in May.A spokesman for RBH has said that the hotel is set to be open by the end of the year: ldquoWhile we canrsquot give an exact opening date at the moment, the hotel is scheduled to open in quarter  of  she said.Molo Hotels changed their name from Polocom Developments in .Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Leading Inverness football figure to live on with launch of fundraising campaign
story: THE memory of a leading Inverness football figure will live on with the launch of a fundraising campaign to help renal patients and raise awareness of kidney failure.Sandyrsquos Army will be launched in memory of Sandy Corcoran, the founder of Inverness City Ladies, on what would have been his th birthday.Mr Corcoran, who died three days before Christmas, had lived with type one diabetes for many years and then developed kidney failure resulting in him undergoing long dialysis sessions in Raigmore Hospitalrsquos renal unit.His family, including we, Valerie, son Steven and daughter Ashley Mackinnon, plus five grandchildren, are now raising funds for the unit at a dinner dance featuring live music and comedians at the cityrsquos Kingsmillrsquos Hotel on April .At the stroke of midnight, Sandyrsquos Army will be launched heralding more fundraising events in the coming year.Mrs Mackinnon said just  tickets remain for the event after  were snapped up in three days.ldquoWe want the night to be a massive celebration and we want to remember what an unbelievable person he was, she said. ldquoIt is going to be a sensational tribute to him as a person helping others and he would have wanted it no other way. It will be a hard day but I feel that being with those who loved him it will make it easier.Although Mr Corcoran was diagnosed with diabetes  years ago, he managed his condition but then developed kidney failure five years ago.With the support of his family, he started home dialysis but when it became too dficult he had to swap to six-hour sessions three days a week in the renal unit.ldquoThe unit became like a family to us, Mrs Mackinnon recalled. ldquoThey were just incredible to my dad. I noticed he was never on his own. They work tirelessly  hours a day, seven days a week.He was due to have a kidney and pancreas transplant but then developed bone marrow failure resulting in him having blood transfusions which meant he could not have a transplant.Sadly, Mr Corcoran, who was also the manager of Inverness Precast, died on December . Over  people attended his funeral.ldquoHe faced everything with the most unbelievable courage. I never once heard dad complain, Mrs Mackinnon said.She added that the family want to give something back to the renal unit and, as well as the dinner, planned fundraisers include an ascent of Ben Nevis.ldquoThis is a way of helping others through his memory.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: New bridge over the River Nairn is on track for summer
story: TEMPORARY weight restrictions on a busy rural road could be scrapped by the summer.Work to build a new crossing over the River Nairn to replace the ageing White Bridge is ldquoprogressing well and on track for completion by early summer, Highland Council has confirmed.The road bridge, which dates back to the th century and is category A listed, spans the river on the B route between Clephanton and Cawdor.It has been struggling to cope with heavy modern traffic and a weight limit of  tonnes has been in operation while a new bridge is built and the road realigned. The weight restriction has caused disruption for farmers, forestry vehicles and tour buses, which have been unable to use the existing bridge in the interim.The pound. million project is being handled by Dingwall-based RJ McLeod .Confirming that work is on track, Highland Council said that construction of the abutments for the new crossing beams was now complete and the beams were successfully hoisted into place this week.Now that the four beams are in place, contractor RJ McLeod will proceed with decking out between beams in preparation for concrete casting.Highland councillors in the Nairn and Cawdor ward, and Culloden and Ardersier wards ndash whose boundaries are spanned by the new crossing ndash have welcomed the progress being made.During the works the existing route has remained open to drivers, however all road users have been reminded about the -tonne weight restriction.Any vehicles which weigh more than this limit should use the ersion route, which goes via the A, A and B roads.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: New Lochardil hotel owner pledges to make investment
story: NEW owners of a well established Inverness hotel have promised more investment to make it even more attractive to visitors.Lochardil House Hotel has become the second mainland hotel bought by Skye-based Perle Hotels and the group has been advertising for staff to get ready for the summer.The Victorian mansion, which was built in  as the home of Inverness MP Charles Fraser-Mackintosh, has been a hotel since .It was previously owned by Eileen Fraser, who bought the hotel in . More recently she has expanded the hotel with the addition of a purpose-built banqueting suite, a conservatory restaurant, new kitchens and a separate  bedroom garden wing, more than doubling its accommodation provision.Perle Hotels marketing manager Nina Ghita said the group wanted to build on the hotelrsquos heritage and had no plans to change its name.ldquoWe want to keep those unique quirks and the history. Those are really important, but there are always things that can be improved, she said.ldquoWe focus on the Highlands and Islands and we invest quite heavily into the hotels, provide more jobs and just try and make something special within the area. The same thing will be happening with Lochardil. Obviously the hotel is in a really good position as it is. We donrsquot have any concrete plans as yet, but there will be heavy investment down the road.Unlike the grouprsquos previous hotels, which required major renovations, she does not anticipate anything so drastic. There are no immediate plans to add other north hotels to the group, but Ms Ghita pointed out there were opportunities available all the time.ldquoWe are a growing company, she said. ldquoThere will be future expansion plans but nothing concrete at the moment.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: One man campaign to safeguard cyclists
story: Allie Middletonfrom Balnakyle Road is concerned about the visibility of a cycle path which cuts through trees and merges with the east junction with Lochy Road and he is urging locals to campaign for improved awareness and traffic calming measures.ldquoI just happen to live opposite the cycle track. I would never be able to forgive myselfsomething happened and I hadnrsquot done something about it, said Mr Middleton.He is particularly concerned that many drivers do not know the cycle track is there because it is set back roughly  metres from the road, through the garden of the Green Drive Hall.Mr Middleton said when the cycle path was upgraded three years ago, a barrier was removed which had separated the path clearly from the road.There is now a sign at the end of the path before it meets the road, warning cyclists to dismount. But Mr Middleton said that the sign was being ignored and there was a danger at the bend where cyclists meet traffic.Speed reducing tables have been installed at the site, but Mr Middleton said: ldquoCars are going over the raised tables at mph and then drivers are putting the foot down in between them.He has reported his concerns to the council who carried out a survey in May last year. It revealed the average speed in the mph zone at the busiest time in the morning is .mph.He is now urging the council to instal signs to alert the drivers to the oncoming cyclists or a speed indicating devicewhich will show road users their speed.The path is used by pupils from Lochardil Primary, Inverness Royal Academy Holm Primary and the Gaelic school.Mr Middleton fears young people on the path may not be seen by fast moving vehicles: ldquoWe have crossed this road many times andin the company of two or four of my grandchildren this is more dficult, the main reason for this is in estimating the speed of accelerating vehicles since the tables were installed said Mr Middleton.A Highland Council spokeswoman said: ldquoA mph zone was recently installed in the Culduthel Lochardil area at the request of the community council. The scheme which encompasses Balnakyle Road includes appropriate signage and associated traffic calming features. Highland Council are monitoring speeds and will be making the police awarea persistent speeding problem is demonstrated. The concerns... will be investigated.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Parents criticise new school bus service across Inverness
story: SCHOOL bus services have been in chaos since a council contract changed hands at the start of the month it has been claimed.Parents say a move to double up dedicated school runs with services for the general public since transport giant Stagecoach took over the Highland Council schools contract from DE Coaches on January  has seen pupils regularly forced to endure late-running and dangerously overcrowded buses.Police have also confirmed they are investigating allegations that pupils were threatened with a weapon on board a bus between Kirkhill and Charleston Academy on January .Mum Carol Paterson, whose daughter travels from Croy to Culloden Academy, said the problems are known about across Inverness.ldquoThe children at Croy are waiting sometimes up to  minutes in freezing conditions because the buses are now regularly late, she said.ldquoAnd when they board the bus there are not enough seats.Jools Lawson, whose daughter attends Charleston Academy, said: ldquoKids are regularly having to stand on a jam-packed bus or being put off altogether and told to wait for another one.ldquoThe service is disgusting and Stagecoach brush our complaints under the carpet.Posts from a private Facebook group set up for parents of pupils using school buses and shown to the Inverness Courier make clear the extent of unhappiness since the changeover.Other alleged incidents include children being put off a bus beside a busy main road without a pavement and two incidents involving Inverness Royal Academy pupils ndash one where a bus did not turn up at home time and another where the bus was too small to accommodate them.Highland Council has issued two separate statements in response to concerns raised ndash one with regard to a public service operating en route to Inverness Gaelic Primary stating it is unlikely to involve ldquoroutes which the public are likely to want to use and another on the Charleston Academy-Kirkhill route stating ldquomeasures have been put in place to make improvements.Despite this an online petition has been launched calling for the reinstatement of dedicated school services.Signed by almost  people so far it states: ldquoWhen putting our children on a school bus it used to be the case that it was only school children on these buses, therefore anyone travelling was accounted for and any incidents easily dealt with and tracked.ldquoNow we have opened the floodgates to allowing our children to be exposed to anything on these buses.Councillor for Culloden and Ardersier, Glynis Campbell-Sinclair, said Highland Council needs to launch its own investigation into whether there is a serious problem with how buses taking pupils to and from schools operate.ldquoThey cannot jam pack children onto buses like pilchards and hope there is not going to be an accident - especially in this weather, she said.ldquoEvery parent that sends their child to school by bus is depending on the council to ensure that happens safely.ldquoIt is the councilrsquos responsibility as corporate parent to ensure these children get to school safely.A spokeswoman for Stagecoach North Scotland said: ldquoSince we started operating the additional school contracts on January  there have been some issues with capacity we have identied and are working to resolve.ldquoWe are working closely with Highland Council to resolve these problems by issuing school children with passes allocating them to specic buses to prevent the overloading problems we have seen.She added that in terms of the issues raised by Mrs Paterson an title: Site for Inverness homes not acceptable
story: Councillor Ken Gowans hit out at the application by agent Bracewell-Stirling for DMPM Services.He said the site was not zoned for housing and would pile pressure on local school rolls which are already well over  per cent capacity.ldquoWhile we need more affordable houses, any development must be part of the local plan, and this development is not.ldquoThis is likely to generate more unacceptable pressures on infrastructure which is already struggling to cope at the moment.ldquoWhile developers pay contributions towards education, it doesnrsquot change the fact that local schools are beyond full, and the councilrsquos school roll projections indicate these will worsen in the short to medium term, he said.Highlands MSP and road safety campaigner David Stewart also expressed some concern: ldquoI am mindful that the dual A will be at one side of this site and the rural B road will extend along another side of the site.ldquoAs it stands, this particular road has no pavement for pedestrians and this would be an issue that would cause me concern.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: Work starts on new outlets at Eastgate Shopping Centre
story: WORK has begun at the Eastgate Shopping Centre in Inverness to develop four food outlets.The units, suitable for restaurant or bar operators, are being created by the reconfiguration of two existing shops fronting Falcon Square.Burger King UK is the first operator to sign up while talks are ongoing with operators for the other units.In addition, a new kiosk will be created fronting the Falcon Square mall entrance. Possible uses include an outlet for a food takeaway.The development comes as the cityrsquos nearby rail station is set to undergo a pound million upgrade while a public consultation is currently ongoing into a bold vision to transform Academy Street to make it more pedestrian-friendly.Alasdair Murdoch, chief executive of Burger King UK, said: ldquoWe are excited to expand the Burger King brand in Inverness and look forward to welcoming guests to experience the great-tasting, high-quality food that has delighted Burger King customers for  years.Local building and construction company Compass expects to hand over the units in late May to be fitted out and managing director Thom Macleod is delighted it has been appointed principal contractor for the redevelopment of the former Monsoon and Mamas and Papas unit.ldquoHaving been involved extensively in the planning of the project, it is pleasing to now be making preparations for the works to get formally under way on site, he said.Previous proposals involved an extension into Falcon Square or rooftop bar but were altered to attract a wider range of operators.Centre manager Jackie Cuddy said it will be business usual while work proceeds.ldquoWe are delighted to see the works progressing after several enforced delays over the yearsshe said. ldquoThe market may have changed since we first started out on this journey but we are still optimistic that we can provide a great addition to the night time economy of Inverness with this development.Thursday  Jan  : AM

title: mcinnes wants to add a wee bit more to aberdeen squad
story: Dons boss Derek McInnes today confirmed he hopes to bring in one more signing before the transfer window closes.The winter window shuts tomorrow and McInnes will step up his attempts to strengthen his squad.Aberdeen have been linked with the potential loanof former Dons winger Jonny Hayes from Celtic.However, it is understood finances would rule out any chance of the Reds taking Hayes back to Pittodrie.Aberdeen moved into the fth round of the Scottish Cup last night with a - replay defeat of Stenhousemuir at Ochilview.They will now face Championship Queen of the South in the last .McInnes said: “I would still like to maybe bring one more inwe could.“On the day of the cup tie I just took a step back from it as I was just trying to concentrate on the game.“The game required our full focus.“We will see where we are and will make a few calls after the game.“However, we are getting bodies back as Devlin is not too far away and Mark Reynolds is back.“Defensively we are not too bad and we have some good attacking options and some youngsters coming through.“If we don’t manage to bring anyone in it will not be the end of the world.“But just for the challenges ahead I would like to add a wee bit more to the squadwe can.”Aberdeen also enquired about the possibility of bringing Celtic’s Scotland international winger Lewis Morgan in on loan until the end of the season.However, Sunderland boss Jack Ross, who worked with Morgan at St Mirren, looks set to secure him.McInnes said there have been a number of players the Dons have enquired about in this window.He said: “There have been a few players we have asked the question about and spoke to ious managers about.“Some conversations have been more positive than others.“But just because you ask the questionthere is anything definite in it.”Meanwhile, McInnes confirmed Scotland international centre-back Scott McKenna is set to miss the next two to three games with a hamstring injury.McKenna was sent for a scan on Monday to assess the injury that forced him off in the - draw with Kilmarnock.McInnes said: “As expected it was not as bad as the last time – when Scott got injured against Rangers, when he was out for six, seven weeks.“Scott will miss the next two or three games, but will hopefully be back for the cup tie.“The good news is it was nothing signicant and was just like a grade one tear.“He will hopefully be back before too long.”Aberdeen eased into the next round with goals from Niall McGinn, Sam Cosgrove, Greg Stewart and an own goal.It was Stewart’s first goal since ing to Pittodrie on a loan deal from Birmingham until the end of the season.Stewart spent last season on loan at Pittodrie, but spent the first half of this campaign at Kilmarnock.McInnes said: “It was a brilliant finish as he just got enough pace on the dink to get it over the line.”Aberdeen had been held - at Pittodrie in the initial tie having led -.In the aftermath of that draw McInnes admitted his side took their foot off the gas.This time the Reds were ruthless and there was never any chance of a repeat of Stenhousemuir’s famous - Scottish Cup defeat of the Dons in .McInnes said: “Our approach in the first game was absolutely spot on and we got the first goal.“We were just wasteful with chances and were maybe a bit rusty.“We were punished.“In the replay it was all about having that focus, calmness and using our experience.“We have been a good cup team over the last few years and I get reminded of the time Aberdeen lost at Stenhousemuir to Terry Christie’s team often enough.“It is easy to see why people maybe look at this as trickier.“But the players approached it right and we were clinical in the first half.“We spoke at half-time about making sure there was no sloppiness, so I was disappointed that we lost the goal.“To score from inside our six-yard box isn’t good enough and we need to make sure that was better.“But by and large there were some good performances and we stretched them and worked them.“We looked like a proper team and I am delighted we managed to score four goals and threatened to score more.”

title: 119000 children in need cash boost for charlie house
story: An Aberdeen charity has been given a whopping £, in order to help children and babies with complex disabilities.Charlie House was awarded the six-figure sum, which will be paid out over three years, from the BBC’s Children In Need fund.Bosses at the charity said the incredible sum will “change the lives” of children across the north-east.Charlie House was founded in  and currently runs a number of services for youngsters with complex disabilities and or le-limiting conditions and their families.These include activity and siblings clubs, one-to-one support, annual adventure trips and a community nurse who works in hospitals.The funding will be used to provide therapeutic, supportive and fun activities for young people in order to allow siblings to better come to terms with their brother or sister’s le-limiting condition.It’s hoped that in turn will allow them to better manage their emotions, develop new friendships and experience a more positive home environment.Tracy Johnstone, chairwoman and founder of Charlie House, said: “We could not expand our reach to families and young people in the north-east of Scotland without the support of BBC Children In Need. This grant will go on to change the lives of so many young people and give them the support they need, when they need it.“This project support will improve the mental and emotional wellbeing of siblings of children with complex disabilities and le-limiting conditions by providing one-to-one and group or family therapeutic support, sibling support and pre-and post-bereavement support.”In November Charlie House announced its plans to build a specialist support centre based in four acres of ground at Woodend Hospital.Aimed at providing respite for families, it will also feature a number of dferent facilities, and will be the first of its kind in the north-east.At present, people have to travel more than  miles to the nearest respite centre, which is in Kinross.In the north-east alone, there are more than , babies, children and young people with complex disabilities.The Big Build Appeal aims to raise £ million, which will allow the construction and maintenance of the building.It will comprise eight children’s bedrooms with accompanying family accommodation, and will also have flexible office and meeting space for employees.Florence Burke, national head of Scotland at BBC Children In Need, said: “We are committed to improving the lives of those children and young people who need it most.“Our support to Charlie House will enable them to make real and lasting changes to children with le-limiting conditions and their families across the north-east of Scotland. To quote Charlie House, le is precious, we believe that it should also be full of fun and friendship and look forward to seeing this funding in action.”BBC Children In Need has raised more than £ billion for children and young people across the UK.It supports more than , projects for those facing a range of disadvantages, including living in poverty, being disabled or ill, or experiencing distress, neglect or trauma. title: plans lodged to create 500 600 home coastal community in aberdeen1
story: Plans have been lodged to create a new “coastal community” in Aberdeen – including building  to  new homes.Cognito Oak LLP has applied to Aberdeen City Council to build the new residential development at Cloverhill, Bridge of Don, on land to the east of the A Ellon Road.A new recycling centre, shops, eateries and community facilities have also been proposed for the site, near Bridge of Don Industrial Estate. vw, px"  In a letter, Halliday Fraser Munro, planning consultants for the application, said: “The proposed residential elements would comprise a mix of market and mixed-tenure affordable homes to meet local and market needs.“A range of other uses would also be provided, including the provision of local shops and servicesto create a sustainable mixed-use coastal community within the city.“Other uses will support local employment generation and provide facilities that support the community.”The application is the latest in a series of new housing developments for the area.The Grandhome Trust has planning permission in principle for a community of , homes, including commercial, shopping, leisure and public space.With long-term potential for , homes, the community is being planned and developed by the trust, a family-led entity that has held the land for more than  years.The public will get the chance to view the proposals for Cloverhill at a consultation event planned for Tuesday February  at St Columba’s Church in Bridge of Don.The drop-in exhibition will be manned by members of the design team who will deal with any queries.There will be a number of display  that provide background to the site, illustrate the proposals and explain the planning process.

title: coleman and aliyev impress ardrishaig
story: Robert LaceyUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAs the lights dimmed in Ardrishaig Hall on Saturday January , and the audience chatter subsided, two young men, dressed entirely in black, strode into view.Jâms Coleman sat at the splendid Yamaha grand piano that for all visiting musicians must be such a relief to see, while Jamal Aliyev carefully set the spike of his special Giovanni Gabrielli Cello , an instrument re-discovered after a -year absence from public performance.Then the music began and the dark first notes of Beethoven’s Cello and Piano Sonata op. no. in G minor filled the hall. It was written for Count Friedrich Wilhelm, supposedly simplied for amateurs to play. However, Jamal and Jâms being master musicians showed the power of this often disregarded piece, to be immense. One of the first works to make piano and cello equal musical partners, it is full of ingenious dialogue between the instruments. The structure is unusual, but with such expert performers it delighted the audience who were moved by every turn and twist of this deeply emotional work.Jâms, from North Wales, after remarking on the three ferry crossings required to get to Ardrishaig via Bute, introduced the next piece, Ernest Bloch’s work ‘From Jewish Le’. In a style close to Jamal’s heart and heritage, having been born in Baku Azerbaijan, its three elements, ‘Prayer’, ‘Supplication’ and ‘Jewish Song’, are full of the pathos and sorrow felt by the Jewish nation and also full of the signature augmented intervals and minor key tonality of much of middle eastern musics. How beautully these pieces demonstrated the lyrical qualities of the cello. Jamal’s bow searched for all possible nuances of tone and dynamic as his instrument sang from its lowest notes to a seductive soprano register.The concert continued after the interval with a second Beethoven work. The audience may have noticed a minor kerfuffle at the piano as many pages were rapidly turned before starting. Would it be the ‘Seven Variations’ for cello and piano or the ‘Twelve’, both based on themes from Mozart’s Magic Flute  The ‘Seven Variations’ won, being on the theme from the ‘Pamina’ and ‘Papageno’ duet entitled ‘In men, who know the feeling of love’. This work exhibits Beethoven’s practised ingenuity in the iation form and brought a lighter mood to the programme.Jâms Coleman introduced the final work, Frank Bridge’s Cello Sonata. He told of the four years of torment for the composer as he struggled to express his feelings about the First World War, finally finishing the composition in . The adagio in the piece caused the composer the most dficulty as he struggled with ambivalence about his own pacist views. Jâms and Jamal dealt with the challenges of this complex work which tracks huge changes in the world of music composition that were under way at that time. Again, the lyrical powers of the cello came to the fore as did the virtuosic requirements heaped on the pianist. Despite its undoubted innovations, this piece generously reaches out to its audience. Bridge uses the new musical freedoms only when justied, being happy toto more traditional tonal stability in the lyrical sections.Fulfilled, but not overburdened by the weightiness of the final piece, the audience applauded Jamal and Jâms back to the concert room to perform the ‘Swan’ from Saint-Saens ‘Carnival of the Animals’ as encore. This piece so beautully confirmed the excellence of Jamal’s playing and the superb quality of his quite special instrument.PIC:Jamal Aliyev and Jâms Coleman. no_aJamalandJam

title: ayr blind swimmer takes water
story: NewsAyr blind swimmer takes to water to raise cash for charityAyr girl Fern Walker, will attempt more than  s over the coming weeks.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN NewsFern is splitting her charity swim between Prestwick and Troon pools "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA blind swimmer has taken to the water in a bid to raise charity cash. Ayr girl Fern Walker, will attempt more than  s over the coming weeks. The -year-old is putting in the aqua miles at her favourite pools in Prestwick and Troon in the hope of raising more than pound. Fern, who lives with Bardet-Biedl Syndrome , is completing the challenge with the aid of her care team at Partners For Inclusion. She said: “I really enjoy my swimming and I come to the pool three times a week. “It will be tough to complete all these s and I’ve just started out – but I’m enjoying it so far.” BBS is a rare genetic disorder with symptoms including sight loss, obesity and reduced kidney . Like many other sufferers, Fern was also born with extra digits. The condition affects just one in , people across the world.   Sister Leigh, , said: “We’re all incredible proud of Fern and what she’s trying to achieve. “She was diagnosed with BBS at a very young age and her condition, particularly her sight, has deteriorated through time. “But she is never one to complain so this is typical of her attitude – she’s just determined to get out there and do something worthwhile.” Staff at Prestwick and Troon pools are helping encourage Fern during her bid, as she tackles up to  s at a time during each session. And the former Mainholm Academy pupil hopes to complete the marathon water trip while stacking up the cash for BBS UK. The charity provides support for those living with the condition and their carers. Leigh added: “It would be niceFern’s story going public could help with her fundraising effort. “She has her small group of friends and carers but it would mean the world to her to get support from further afield and raise as much as she can.” •To donate visit https:www.justgiving fundraising fern-walker

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayr united 2 inverness 3
story: NewsAyr United  Inverness : John Roberston hails Somerset Park among best grounds in worldThe Inverness gaffer was full of praise for the old fashioned surroundings as his side clung on in the face of a stirring fightback.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNathan Austin puts Caley - up "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn Robertson hailed Somerset Park as one of the best grounds in the WORLD after Caley held off a storming Ayr fightback. Inverness were three up and on easy street after a crazy opening  minutes which saw United gt-wrap the game. But a Lawrence Shankland inspired comeback almost grabbed a share of the spoils for Ian McCalls title contenders. A relieved Robertson said: Had it finished - you wouldnt have been surprised. Somerset Park is one of these grounds that sucks you inyou give them a snf. Its a good throwback and their fans make it intimidating and a good atmosphere for teams when you lose a goal. Its brilliant...one of the best grounds in the world to come and play your football. In the past we might have lost a game like this so Im delighted.  Ayr knew a win here would take them top of the Championship and started well with Robbie Crawford missing a good chance in the first minute. But they soon hit the self destruct button as their defence went AWOL to allow Nathan Austin in for a double before Liam Polworth rammed home a third. The game looked over with barely  minutes on the clock and shellshocked Ayr took time to regroup. Coventry-bound Michael Rose rocked the post with a header before Michael Moffat drew a fingertip save from Cammy Mackay. McCall turned to the bench at half time and introduced top gun Shankland who immediately turned the tide. He set up Declan McDaid to haul Ayr back into the contest with a close range finish eight minutes after the restart. And a resurgent Ayr thought they had a penalty when Carl Tremarco appeared to handle in the box but ref Nick Walsh waved away loud protests. United continued to pour forward as the clock ticked down and Shankland set up a grandstand finish when slamming home a  yard free kick with five minutes left.  But their comeback proved too little too late as Inverness clung on. Ayr boss McCall said: Im just gutted. Weve conceded three goals and at least two of them were gted with just crazy defending. And were the team with the best defensive record in the league. I think a draw would’ve been fair but it’s just one of those nights.
